[Page 1 of 20]
Minimum wages for domestic workers: impact evaluation of the Indian
experience
Rohan Ravindra Gudibandeb, Arun Jacoba,⇑
aOfﬁce of the United Nations Resident Coordinator, 8th ﬂoor, World Trade Center (WTC), 1191 Corniche El Nil, Beaulac, Cairo, Egypt
bESOC, Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs, Princeton, NJ 08544, USA
article info
Article history:
Accepted 24 February 2020
Available online 25 March 2020
Keywords:
Minimum WagesDomestic WorkIndiaInformal SectorEmploymentImpact EvaluationWage Distributions
Decent Workabstract
What impact does minimum wage legislation have on wages and employment opportunities in an
informal sector in a developing country? The paper answers this question in the context of minimumwage legislation for domestic workers in India over the period of 2004–2012. Combining, matching
procedure with difference-in-difference estimation approach, supported by extensive robustness
checks, the paper estimates both the short-run and the long-run impact of the legislation on real wagesand employment. Results show a positive impact of the legislation on real wages in the shortrun, whilethere is limited evidence of this effect persisting in the long-run. Further, the legislation did not seem
to have any impact at the extensive margin on the probability of being employed as a domestic worker
over short or long run. Our analysis further reveals that the wages of majority of workers remain belowthe minimum wage. Available evidence from the ground, in line with theoretical predictions, point
towards weak enforcement of the legislation as the potential driving factor of observed results. As
India recently extended national level minimum wage for all workers, the paper provides a cautionarytale on the potential pitfalls of implementation of this legislation in informal sector and suggests some
ways to overcome the same.
/C2112020 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
1. Introduction
The impact of minimum wage legislations on employment and
wages has been the subject of extensive empirical work.1While the
majority of existing studies focus on the impact of minimum wage
laws in developed countries, there is an emerging focus ondeveloping countries exploring similar empirical questions. Most of
these studies show mixed evidence on the impact of minimum wage
laws. The ﬁndings suggest that while minimum wage laws tend to
increase wages at the intensive margin, the impact on employment
at the extensive margin is unclear with results showing positive,
neutral or a negative impact.
However, the empirical literature on the the impact of mini-
mum wages for informal sector sector, which contributes to more
than 60% of the global employment ( ILO, 2018 ), is still an emerging
area of research. One of the most understudied groups within
informal sector is that of domestic workers comprising of employ-
ees in private households working as maid servants, cook, watch
man and other jobs.2The paper asks, what impact does minimum
wage legislation have on an informal sector such as domestic work?
Does it improve the earnings and employment opportunities of
workers? The paper studies the short and long run impact of theminimum wage legislation on wages and employment opportunities
for domestic workers in India. The paper relies on four rounds of a
cross-sectional national sample survey (NSS 1999, 2004, 2009 and

[Page 2 of 20]
2012 rounds). This study exploits state level heterogeneity in mini-
mum wage legislation across states in India over 2004 and 2012.3
To overcome the limitation of lack of panel data, our identiﬁcationstrategy combines matching with difference in difference estima-
tions. The matching of domestic workers within treatment states
with their counter parts in control states, both before and after treat-
ment period, on a set of observable characteristics help us to create
suitable counterfactual. The paper then analyzes the impact of the
minimum wage laws on both the intensive (wages) and extensive
margins (employment opportunity).
India makes an interesting case due to several reasons. Firstly,
according to National Domestic Worker’s Movement in India, the
number of domestic workers in India range from 4.2 million to 50
million, implying this is a relatively large sector within India.4Sec-
ondly, domestic household workers were one of informal sector occu-pational groups not covered by the national minimum wage law in
India until very recently (August 2019). One of the primary reasons
for the non inclusion of the domestic services sector in India under
the National Minimum Wage act of 1948 has been the fact that it is
a very personalized (informal) service within a private household.
After renewed struggle by domestic workers, a few states in India
brought domestic services under coverage of minimum wage laws
over the past decade. Pressure has been mounting from civil society
organisations and domestic worker unions on other States to do the
same. However, with the passage of the Code on Wages Bill in August
2019, all informal sector workers including domestic workers have
come under a minimum a wage law for the ﬁrst time. Hence, compil-
ing lessons from the states that pioneered implementation of mini-
mum wages for informal sector like domestic worker is very timely,
as it can provide insights on the issues that India might confront on
the implementation of the new Code on Wages Bill.
The existing empirical literature on the impact of minimum
wage legislation for domestic workers in India are mostly qualita-
tive (see Section 3). This literature primarily focuses on how the
minimum wages were notiﬁed and implemented in each of the four
states in India. The case-analysis at the micro level suggest that the
minimum wage laws for domestic workers were found wanting in
their construction, implementation and effectiveness vis- /C18a-vis
other work sectors ( Neetha, 2009; Neetha, 2013; Neetha, 2013a;
Eluri & Singh, 2013 ). Hence there is a need to quantify the impact
of the minimum wage laws for domestic workers in India. Studying
impact of any legislation on the informal sector is challenging. Most
importantly, there are limited number of surveys that systemati-
cally account for informal sector workers. Further, the informal nat-
ure of the sector implies that very often there are no written
contracts or formal records of transactions that can be exploited
for analytical work. In this paper, we overcome some of these lim-
itations by identifying precise informal sector workers, employed in
domestic work in India from the national sample surveys and col-
lect information pertaining to individual employment and wages
directly or from their household heads. By following the cohort of
domestic workers over repeated cross-sectional surveys we try to
delineate the impact of minimum wages legislation.
Based on the data reported by domestic workers, the paper
ﬁnds a strong positive impact of the legislation on real wages in
the short-run between, 2004 and 2009, while we do not ﬁnd evi-
dence of signiﬁcant positive impact on wages in the long run by
2012. There seems to be no impact of the legislation at the exten-
sive margin on the probability of being employed as a domestic
sector worker in both the short and the long-run. However in the
short run, the magnitude of impact on real wages seems to be largeindicating a 30 percent increase in mean real wages compared to
control states. The results are consistent for different speciﬁcations
and for a number of robustness and sensitivity checks (see Sections
7). In explaining the mechanism that drives the results, we conduct
a variety of tests to distinguish between supply-side effects from
worker mobility and enforcement. With the available evidence,
we lean towards weak monitoring and enforcement mechanism
of the law as the key factor driving the observed results in terms
of wages and employment.
Our results are in line with the existing, albeit limited, literature
from India evaluating impact of minimum wages ( Menon & Van
Der Meulen Rodgers, 2017; Menon & Van Der Meulen Rodgers,
2018; Soundararajan, 2019 ).Menon and Van Der Meulen Rodgers
(2017) explores gender disaggregated impact of minimum wages
in rural and urban areas. Menon and Van Der Meulen Rodgers
(2018) studies the impact of minimum wages on child labour.
Soundararajan (2019) analyse the interaction between minimum
wages and enforcement in the case of construction sector workers.
The general conclusion from these studies is that minimum wage
laws have an impact on wages, especially at or above the median
of the wage distribution. In terms of employment, minimum wages
seems to have had no impact in urban areas, with some positive
effect on paid labour in rural sector. With the focus on urban areas,
our results are in line with the existing ﬁndings of these studies.
However, we ﬁnd that the positive impact of minimum-wages on
wages disappears in the long-run. Hence, the beneﬁts of expanding
minimum wage coverage to all casual workers (like domestic
workers) may not necessarily deliver the kind of beneﬁts in terms
of reduced wage inequality, poverty and the gender pay gap as
simulated by Belser and Rani (2011) for India.
The results of the paper are also in line with theoretical models
presented in Basu, Chau, and Kanbur (2010) which highlights the
need to look at the interaction of imperfect competition, enforce-
ment and commitment from Government on the impact of mini-
mum wages on labour market outcomes. Hence, the key policy
message of our paper is that highly vulnerable informal sector
workers need a lot more than just an ‘announcement effect’ of min-
imum wage legislation in order to make a real positive impact on
their livelihoods (see Section 6).
The paper contributes to the literature in the following manner.
First, the study attempts to quantify the effect of minimum wage
laws for domestic workers on both real wages and employment,
and contributes to the emerging literature studying the labour
effects of minimum wages in informal sector settings both in short
and long run. Second, the study adds to the limited literature
studying the impact of minimum wages on the informal sector in
India. While 86 % of employment take place in the informal sector,
there is very limited research on the impact of minimum wages inIndia ( Broecke et al., 2017 ). Third, it provides validation of existing
theoretical literature on the impact of minimum wages in informal
sectors, with a focus on enforcement.
The rest of the paper is divided into following sections. Section 2
provides a brief overview of existing literature on impact evalua-
tion of minimum wages, with a focus on informal sector workers.
Section 2.2will give the theoretical motivation informing our anal-
ysis. Section 3will discuss the domestic work sector in India and
describe the implementation of minimum wages. Section 4will
describe the data and empirical methodology used in the paper.
Section 5will provide our main results. It starts with exploring
the impact of the legislation on wages, followed by discussion of
impact of the legislation on employment. Section 6discusses
potential mechanisms that could drive the observed results. Sec-
tion 7describes extensive robustness checks and sensitivity analy-
sis for the key results. Some of the key robustness checks
conducted involve verifying parallel trends assumption, common
support, state-time trends, checking effects in a placebo sector,3In India four states introduced minimum wages for domestic workers over 2004
and 2009. Karnataka was the ﬁrst to institute minimum wages for domestic workersin 2004, followed by Bihar and Andhra Pradesh in 2007 and Rajasthan in 2008.
4http://ndwm.org/domestic-workers/ .2 R.R. Gudibande, A. Jacob / World Development 130 (2020) 104943

gender dis-aggregated analysis and accounting for distributional
changes between pre and post treatment samples. Section 8con-
cludes with some policy implications of our results.
2. Literature
2.1. Empirical Literature
The empirical literature on the the impact of minimum wages
for informal sector in developing countries while still relatively
small, is an emerging area of empirical research. Most of these
studies focus on Latin American countries using ﬁrm or sectoral
level data ( Bell, 1997; Carneiro, 2001; Maloney & Mendez,
2013; Maloney, 2004; Lemos et al., 2004; Almeida & Carneiro,
2005; Neumark et al., 2006; Almeida & Carneiro, 2007; Gindling
& Terrell, 2007; Ronconi, 2008; Lemos, 2009; Gindling & Terrell,
2009; Almeida & Carneiro, 2011; Khamis, 2013; Broecke et al.,
2017; Menon & Van Der Meulen Rodgers, 2017; Menon & Van
Der Meulen Rodgers, 2018; Soundararajan, 2019 ). The main ﬁnd-
ings are the following. First, minimum wage legislation com-
pressed the wage distribution for both the informal and formal
labor market and contributed to positive impact on wages. Sec-
ond, minimum wage seem to have had a mixed effect on employ-
ment outcomes. Some studies point to negative employment
effects of varying degree, while others ﬁnd positive employment
effect in informal sectors and a negative employment effect in for-
mal sectors. While some studies have pointed to null or negligible
employment effects across both informal and formal labor
markets.5
The variation in these effects seem to be related to the level of
minimum wages and the degree of informality. In low minimum
wage settings with high degree of informality the null or negligible
employment effects seem to persists across different countries
(Broecke et al., 2017 ). When it comes to vulnerability of workers
most of the existing studies deﬁne it as those who have relatively
low skills or education, or those who are relatively young or those
who are women ( Maloney, 2004 ).
Therefore in order to evaluate the impact of minimum wage
legislation for vulnerable groups in developing countries it is
important to focus on speciﬁc sectors that can uncover the source
of informality. One such sector is the domestic work sector, where
there is little possibility of market driven social protection for
workers unless the state directly intervenes through legislation.
Further this sector in many developing countries are dominated
by vulnerable groups such as young or female workers who have
little bargaining power ( D’souza, 2010 ). This sector is especially
under-studied within the broad empirical literature on minimum
wages. There are only a handful of studies conﬁned to few geo-
graphical areas such as the USA and South Africa ( Mattila, 1973;
Dinkelman & Ranchhod, 2012; Bhorat et al., 2013 ). The main ﬁnd-
ings so far suggest (i) private households are very quick to ﬁnd sub-
stitutes as the relative costs of domestic workers increase due tominimum wages, (ii) on average minimum wage laws increase
wages for domestic workers even in the absence of full compliance
and (iii) there is little to no signiﬁcant impact on employment for
domestic workers. The empirical literature on the impact of mini-
mum wage laws for precise informal sectors such as domestic
work, is limited, largely owing to paucity of data and a lack of min-
imum wage legislation. Hence there is a need to expand minimum
wage studies for domestic workers in other developing countries
where they constitute a large proportion of informal employment.
The paper tries to ﬁll this gap by evaluating the labor market
impact of minimum wage legislation in the domestic work sectorfor a large developing country. The geographic focus of this paper
is India. India in general has been relatively understudied within
the minimum wage literature with very limited literature on the
labor market impact of minimum wages across both formal and
informal sectors.
2.2. Theoretical literature
The effects of the minimum wage legislation depends on the
labor market structure and enforcement rates. There are two con-
trasting predictions. First, if the labor market is perfectly compet-
itive one would expect an increase in wages and a decline in
employment ( Stigler, 1946 ). Second, in imperfect markets with
monopsony, employers might have a wage setting power unlike
competitive markets allowing them to pay wages to a worker
below his or her value of marginal product ( Stigler, 1946 ). Hence
introduction of a minimum wage legislation depending on how
large is the difference with prevailing labor market wages could
lead to an increase in employment. In other words given the degree
of monopsonistic power of the employer to set wages, a relatively
low minimum wage
vis/C0/C18a/C0visvalue of marginal product of the
worker, the employer can pay the minimum wage and still employ
more workers until the minimum wage is equal to the value of
marginal product. The increase in employment can vary from no
loss, negative or positive gains depending upon the characteristics
of the targeted work sector such as the degree of informality or
vulnerability.
In developing countries, low wage occupations such as the
domestic work sector are likely to be monopsonistic where
employers are more likely to have an inﬂuence in setting wages
due to (i) low skill requirements for the work involved, or (ii) high
costs involved in worker migration to high wage areas ( Coffey,
Papp, & Spears, 2015; Bryan & Morten, 2019 ).6This means any
effective wage or employment outcomes from minimum wage legis-
lation targeting the domestic work sector depends on the degree of
enforcement which pushes employers to comply with the minimum
wage rate. There are two possible outcomes in such a case.
First, if the minimum wage introduced is low and below a given
threshold, with enforcement, it would lower the ratio of the mar-
ginal cost of labor to the minimum wage, increasing employment
in the new equilibrium. However a high minimum wage above
the threshold would induce an increase in the ratio and hence
reduce employment in the new equilibrium, implying an inverted
V shaped relationship between employment and the minimum
wage distributions.7
Second, Basu et al. (2010) demonstrates that the enforcement
rate ( k, where 0 <k<1) (the probability of the employer being
inspected and any violation being caught) determines how theminimum wage affects the expected marginal cost and not the true
marginal cost.
8If enforcement is low we should observe negative or
5SeeBroecke et al. (2017) for a comprehensive review on the effects of minimum
wages on employment in emerging economies.6Monopsony in the context of the domestic work sector does not mean only one
buyer. It refers to monopsonistic competition where employer’s market power
persists despite competition with other employers given a large number of employerswith free entry ( Bhaskar, Manning, & To, 2002 ).
7SeeSoundararajan (2019) for a review of the theoretical relationship between
minimum wages and employment in low wage - imperfect markets as demonstrated
inBasu et al. (2010) .
8The expected marginal cost is the weighted average of the minimum wage and
the true marginal cost, where the weight is given by a monotonically increasingfunction of kas an interaction with h(Basu et al., 2010 ).hindicates the efﬁciency of
the judicial process and government bureaucracy ( Basu et al., 2010 ). This leads to two
key observations in the presence of a low minimum wage given a threshold ( Basu
et al., 2010 ): (i) a high kwould lower the ratio of the expected marginal cost relative
to the true marginal cost and hence increase employment for a wide range along theminimum wage distribution; (ii) if kis low, then the expected marginal cost would be
lower than the true marginal cost for a relatively smaller range of the minimum wagedistribution.R.R. Gudibande, A. Jacob / World Development 130 (2020) 104943 3

null employment effects along with an increase in wages over a
wider interval of wage distribution. Further, ( Basu et al., 2010 )
shows that in the case of convergence of low enforcement (low val-
ues of k), imperfect competition and imperfect commitment by
Government, turning a blind-eye can indeed be the equilibrium. In
the case of domestic worker sector, these conditions set out by
Basu et al. (2010) seems to hold and help us to partly unravel the
mechanisms behind observed trends in wages and employment.
Hence, the paper provides evidence to verify these theoretical
predictions.
3. Details of the treatment
Until August 2019, the Minimum Wages Act of India 1948 leg-
ally granted a minimum wage for workers in activities listed in the
‘‘employment schedule” of the government, maintained by both
the central and state governments ( Soundararajan, 2019 ). Domes-
tic work is not part of this schedule maintained by the central gov-
ernment in India.
The lack of legal recognition of domestic work is not unique to
India ( D’souza, 2010 ). Some key features of domestic work differ-
entiating it from other similar low skilled informal occupations
are the following ( D’souza, 2010 ); (i) the employment relationship
is invisible or in other words it is often undeclared and has no writ-
ten contract involved; (ii) there is an unequal balance of power
between employer and employee; (iii) a lack of precise job descrip-
tion and (iv) the expectation on the part of the employer to be
available at all times.
In India, the main cited reasons for the exclusion of domestic
workers from the employment schedule are (a) potential large
scale loss of employment opportunities of domestic workers, (b)
the difﬁculty in enforcing the laws protecting the minimum wage
of the workers due to location of work being private space and (c)
the informal employment relation between the domestic worker
and the private household ( Neetha, 2009; Armacost, 1994 ).
However, State governments started taking measures to
improve the condition of domestic workers. By 2012, a total of
seven states implemented minimum wages for domestic workers,
namely, Karnataka, Kerala, Andhra Pradesh (AP), Bihar, Rajasthan,
Jharkhand and Odisha.9Of these states we focus our analysis on Kar-
nataka, which was the ﬁrst to institute minimum wages for domestic
workers in 2004 followed by Bihar and Andhra Pradesh in 2007 and
Rajasthan in 2008.10Among these four states, it was only in Karnataka and Andhra
Pradesh, that unions and organizations working among domestic
workers played a key role in bringing the sector under the purview
of the Act. The implementation of minimum wage laws in
Rajasthan and Bihar were more of a technocratic exercise and the
exact reason for their implementation remains unknown ( Neetha,
2013b ).11All these states deﬁne domestic work in terms of tasks
undertaken and the tasks are listed in their respective minimum
wage notiﬁcation. The tasks listed in the notiﬁcation vary from state
to state but in general they include cooking, cleaning and basic care
work.
The notiﬁcations on the minimum wages were rooted in
the societal understanding of domestic work ( Neetha, 2013 ).
For example, within the legislation domestic work is listed
as non technical and an unskilled occupation. Further, mini-mum wage rates are either ﬁxed for an hour or a day as
opposed to a monthly calculation. Appendix Table A-1 shows
that compared to the minimum wages for similar work in
hotel and restaurant sector, the stipulated minimum wages
for domestic workers are lower in most states. This resonates
with the societal devaluation of house-work as a non produc-
tive work in an unproductive work-space ( Sankaran, 2013 ).
Table 1 summarizes the variations in the legislation among
these four states.
4. Data and empirical strategy
4.1. Data
The paper uses the 55th, 61st, 64th, 66th and 68th rounds of
National Sample Survey (NSS) of India, which corresponds to1999, 2004, 2007, 2009, 2012 respectively in its main anlaysis.
Four states instituted minimum wage laws for domestic workers
namely: Karnataka, Bihar, Andhra Pradesh and Rajasthan instituted
minimum wages between 2004 and 2009. All the four treatment
states notiﬁed minimum wages between 2004 and 2009. This pro-
vides two survey years prior to the treatment and two surveys post
treatment. We have two rounds of the national sample survey
(55th (1999) and 61st (2004) rounds) before the law was instituted
and two rounds of the survey (66th (2009) and 68th (2012)
rounds) after the law came into effect in these four states. The
64th survey round for 2007, with additional migration particulars,
is used for robustness checks.
The survey is at the household level and covers the whole of
the Indian Union. The data is reported by workers or their
household members, the wages reported by workers were not
veriﬁed hence the risk of over or under reporting holds for this
survey just like other national surveys. The sample size at state
level is in proportion to its population and at least 16 ﬁrst
stage sampling units in both rural and urban areas for each
state are included. This allows us to study impact of public
policies at state level. The empirical strategies described below
help address some of the key limitations of repeated cross-
sectional data.
4.2. Empirical strategy
The primary estimation strategy used is difference-in-difference
approach. While the treatment is at the state level the data is at the
individual-district level corresponding to each state. The following
difference-in-difference empirical model is used.9There are three more states namely Tamil Nadu, Maharashtra and Assam that
have included domestic work in their respective state list of scheduled employmentin 2007, 2008 and 2013 respectively but have not ﬁxed any wage rate. Chhattisgarh(2013), Jharkhand (2011) and Kerala (2011) have also extended Rashtriya SwastyaBima Yojana (RSBY), a health insurance scheme to domestic workers as the ﬁrst stepin widening the coverage of welfare schemes to this occupational group to domestic
workers. Haryana, Tripura, Dadar and Nagar Haveli had also announced minimum
wage for domestic workers by 2012. Our results do not change once we remove themin 2012 long run analysis in the paper (while keeping them in controls in earlierrounds).
10We exclude Kerala, Jharkand and Odisha as treatment from our analysis due to
several reasons. Kerala witnessed an informal norm of minimum wage standards for
domestic workers as early as in 1989 despite the ofﬁcial minimum wage beingnotiﬁed only in 2010 making Kerala a unique case when compared to the treatmentstates in our analysis. Hence we exclude Kerala entirely from our analysis. InJharkhand the minimum wage law was instituted only in 2010 and hence is used onlyin the control group until 2010 and dropped for later period. Until 2012 Odisha was inthe process of including domestic workers in the list of scheduled employment and aminimum wage was ﬁxed only after 2012. Hence, Odisha remains in the control group
in our anaylsis. Our survey data pertains to 1999, 2004, 2009 and 2012, hence we do
not have two post-treatment survey rounds for these states. Therefore, we alsoexclude Jharkhand from the control group in our long run analysis. By 2012, Haryana,Tripura, Dadar and Nagar Haveli had also announced minimum wage for domesticworkers. The results presented in the paper do not change once we remove them inlong run estimations (while keeping them as controls in earlier rounds).

Xidstrepresents different individual and household covari-
ates. It includes age, sex, marital status, education level, land
owned by household and a dummy variable distinguishing
between higher and lower caste categories. These variables
capture vulnerabilities associated with an informal sector such
as domestic work related to gender, youth, low education or
skills in the literature ( Menon & Van Der Meulen Rodgers,
2017 ). In addition, we also use the interactions between these
covariates in some of the speciﬁcations. The reason for con-
ducting regressions with interactions is that some of these
interactions will have very signiﬁcant impact on determining
the wage rates. For instance, gender and caste interaction termwill help capture any additional discrimination faced by
women of lower caste, compared to their higher caste counter-
parts. Various economic, social and cultural dimensions enters
the calculation of wages for domestic sector workers
(Sengupta & Sen, 2013 ) and these interaction terms help to
capture several of such factors.
The paper also adopts a combination of matching and
difference-in-difference approach to estimate the impact of
the minimum wage legislation in these states. For domestic
workers in the treatment states (those that instituted mini-
mum wage legislations), we ﬁnd counterparts in the same
states (treatment states) and non-treatment states, both before
and after treatment through a matching procedure. The differ-
ence in difference of the outcome variables between these
treatment and control group members before and after the
treatment, gives us a measure of the impact of the minimum
wage legislation.
The main advantage of combining the matching and
difference-in-difference methods (MDID) is to weaken the under-
lying assumptions of these two methods used separately. MDID
adopts a common trends assumption - had the treated remain
untreated they would have experienced the same change in out-
comes as that of the control groups ( Blundell & Cost Dias, 2009;
Blundell, Meghir, Costa Dias, & Reenen, 2004 ). Let tand t0be
the time period before and after treatment respectively, X, the
observable characteristics, D¼1 indicates selection for treatment.
Y
0represents the outcome variable in the untreated state. So the
underlying parallel trends assumption of MDID and our basic
difference-in-difference estimation strategy translates to the
following.

With repeated cross section data (like in our case), we need to
ensure that the treatment group members have comparable coun-
terparts in all the three control groups namely - the treated before
treatment, untreated both before and after treatment. By estimat-
ing treatment effect on the treated via matching in the region of
common support we are able to reduce the bias due to non-
overlapping support. The primary common support is determined
where all observations with a propensity score smaller than the
minimum and larger than the maximum in opposite group were
deleted using the minima and maxima criterion.12
Heckman, Ichimura, and Todd (1997) cites some additional
advantages of MDID. It reduces the bias induced by different ques-
tionnaires likely to be used for treatment and control groups as
well as the bias caused by differing local market characteristics
of the control and treatment groups.13
The matching estimator of the treatment effect, aMDID, can be
represented as ( Blundell & Cost Dias, 2009; Heckman et al., 1997 ):
aMDID¼X

Further, we use entropy balancing (represented as ebalance in
our estimation tables) as described in Hainmueller (2012) to sup-
plement the matching and DiD estimations. Entropy balancing pro-
cess ensures balancing of ﬁrst three moments of covariates
between the treatment and control groups. This is achievedthrough a data pre-processing methodology that relies on maxi-
mum entropy re-weighting scheme that calibrates unit weights
so that the re-weighted treatment and control groups have bal-
anced moments in terms of all covariates. Hainmueller (2012)
ﬁnds that this procedure can greatly reduce model dependence
of estimation of treatment effect.
In executing the MDID approach, the paper uses seven match-
ing algorithms, each with its own merit and limitation, as sum-
marised in Caliendo and Kopeinig (2008) . The algorithms used
are kernel density matching, nearest neighbor matching (with
and without replacement), nearest neighbor caliper matchingTable 1

also study the impact of treatment intensity on the key outcome
variables. In the minimum wage literature, the treatment intensity
is most commonly quantiﬁed in terms of wage gap (WG), which is
the difference between the newly instituted minimum wages and
the median wages in the pre-treatment period.

4.3. Sample selection and key variables
How do we identify domestic workers from NSS surveys?
Within the NSS surveys, there is an indicator under the enterprise
type which identiﬁes ‘private households employing maid servant,
watchman, cook, etc’. All workers engaged in this category can besafely classiﬁed as domestic workers. The wage rates and other
details of the workers are reported by the workers themselves,
hence, we can cast aside any reasons for potential exaggeration
of reported wages. The wage rate, is the total weekly wages
received (both cash and in kind) in the previous week. We convert
nominal weekly wages into real wages based on 2004 price
levels.
16Hence our main outcome variable is log real wage. Less than
3 % of the total data in our sample recorded zero values, hence these
observations get removed from our analysis when the log values of
wages are considered.We also study the impact of the legislation on employment
probability as domestic workers among the larger group of ‘casual
workers’ in the economy.
The matching of workers is implemented based on the follow-
ing covariates gender, age, marital status, dummy for lower caste
(whether belongs to scheduled caste (SC), scheduled tribe (ST), or
other backward classes (OBC)), level of education (illiterate, just
literate, primary, middle or higher education), and land owned
by the household.
We restrict our analysis on the impact of the minimum wage
law for domestic workers to urban areas in the state of Karnataka,
Andhra Pradesh, Bihar and Rajasthan.17
Table 2 compares the sample means for all the Indian States
before and after treatment.
5. Results
We analyze the impact of the minimum wage legislation for
domestic workers on two main outcome variables: log real wages
and employment probability. For both these outcome variables we
study the impact using three approaches explained earlier: normal
difference-in-difference, entropy balancing (ebalance), matching
with diff-in-diff (MDID) with different matching procedures includ-
ing kernel density matching, nearest neighbor matching (with and
without replacement), multiple nearest neighbor matching with
three neighbours and replacement (with and without caliper), cali-
per nearest neighbor matching (with and without replacement).
5.1. Impacts on wages
Table 3 provides the estimations for normal difference-in-
difference (DiD) estimations and entropy balanced (ebalance)
DiD estimations for all four treatment states. We ﬁnd statistically
signiﬁcant positive impact under both ordinary DiD and entropy
balanced procedures on real log wages in these treatment states.
The covariates affect the real wages in the expected direction.
For example, belonging to lower caste implied you earned lower
wages, while more educated workers received higher wages com-
pared to less educated counterparts. Estimations show that many
of these interactions are signiﬁcant in determining the bargaining
power and hence the wage levels of domestic sector workers.18The
positive impact of minimum wage legislation holds even in this
speciﬁcation which includes all interactions between relevantcovariates. For all these speciﬁcations we ﬁnd a signiﬁcant and pos-
itive impact of the minimum wage legislation on wages. The magni-
tude of the impact is also very similar.
We next employ the MDID approach to study the impact of
minimum wage legislation on real wages for domestic sector
workers, using various matching algorithms discussed in Sec-
tion 4.2. We match the treatment group members with counter-
parts from these states in the pre-treatment phase and we follow
the same procedure for control group members. The matching is
14Kernel density matching is a non-parametric matching which uses almost all
members of the control group, using appropriate weighting, to create a counter-factual. While nearest neighbor selects the member from the control group who isclosest to each treatment observation in terms of propensity scores. However, there isa risk that the nearest neighbor is in fact quite far in terms of propensity scores and itcan lead to bad matches. To correct for this, caliper matching allows to impose atolerance level on the distance (in this paper we uses a tolerance level of 0.01)
between the matched pairs. In all these cases, matching ‘with replacement’ refers to
the case when the observations from control group can be used multiple times tomatch with treated observations, while, ‘without replacement’ means this is notpermitted.
15We calculated the weekly minimum wages using 8 h work per day and 7 work
days per week. To construct the wage gap, the median weekly wages of each state for
the pre-treatment year 2004 were used.
16We use the food price index of the urban industrial workers provided by the
Reserve Bank of India to convert nominal wages to real wages.17We do not include rural areas for the following reasons, (i) domestic work is
primarily an urban phenomenon, (ii) due to the problems of enforceability ofminimum wage in rural areas, (iii) the National Rural Employment GuaranteeScheme (NREGS), which guarantees 100 days of employment in rural areas, was
introduced in many of the districts within these states since 2006. The scheme would
have had some impact on domestic workers in these rural areas as they were mostlikely to enroll in NREGS work simultaneously. Hence by including rural areas we runthe risk of not being able to distinguish between the impact of NREGS from that of theminimum wage legislation. In rural areas, domestic workers also do agricultural workand some of their tasks cannot be distinguished from agricultural laborers andsometimes they are paid mostly in kind, making the wage measures increasingly
prone to such errors.
18We do not discuss the signs and signiﬁcance of these covariates and their
interactions in this paper as they are not part of the key results. The detailed results oftheir impact can be provided upon request.6 R.R. Gudibande, A. Jacob / World Development 130 (2020) 104943

carried out on all the covariates used in the normal DiD approach.
Since we have a repeated cross sectional data, this procedure
ensures that difference in difference is estimated using matching
of counterparts across different survey rounds, using a set of
observable characteristics. Table 4 gives the result of the MDID
estimation where we cluster the standard errors at state level. Sim-
ilar to the case of entropy balancing and DiD, we ﬁnd a signiﬁcant
positive impact of minimum wage legislation on weekly real
wages. The results also hold for short run MDID estimates where
the standard errors are clustered and interactions between all
the covariates on which the data is matched are included as con-
trols.19We observe that there is a signiﬁcant positive impact of min-
imum wage legislation on weekly real wages. The magnitude of the
impact ranges from 0.32 to 0.49, all signiﬁcant at 1 % level, slightly
higher than the estimates of DiD estimation in Table 3 .Table 5 provide estimations of the long-run impact of the min-
imum wage legislation on real wages between 2004 and 2012. We
ﬁnd that the treatment impact has reduced in magnitude and is
statistically insigniﬁcant in the long run. We also use the MDID
approach and arrive at the exact same conclusion, as shown in
Table 6 . The results suggests that the impact of minimum wage
legislation in these four treatment states seems to have worn off
by 2012.
Why does the treatment effect disappear in the long run? While
we explore this question in detail in the Section 6, the results of the
treatment on employment probability as domestic workers dis-
cussed in the next section already provides some clue.

ask whether the minimum wage legislation increases the probabil-

develop a dummy variable that indicates if the worker is a domes-
tic sector worker or not. As a comparator group, we include the
sample of all casual workers that could provide job alternatives
to domestic workers.20Casual workers are employed informally,
do not receive social security beneﬁts, consists mainly of people
from economically poorer and socially disadvantaged households,
engaged in irregular work, often compensated on a daily basis
(ILO, 2018 ). Hence, similar to domestic work on several counts. We
treat the dummy indicator variable as the outcome and apply a lin-
ear probability model, within the normal and entropy balanced DiD
frameworks described earlier. Table 7 and 8 provide the results. It
seems that there was a secular decline in the overall probability of
being employed as a domestic worker in India since 2004, denoted
by the negative and signiﬁcant coefﬁcient of the Post variable. How-
ever, the treatment effect is statistically insigniﬁcant implying that
there is no evidence of impact of minimum wage legislation on the
probability of being employed as a domestic worker.
In South Africa, Dinkelman and Ranchhod (2012) ﬁnd that
despite strong positive impact on wages of domestic sector work-
ers, there was no evidence of any impact at the extensive margin
following the minimum wage legislation. Our conclusions seem
to resonate with the South African evidence in this respect. Further,
it helps to partially rule out the possibility that the lack of signiﬁ-
cant impact on real wages in the long-run was due to changes in
employment options for workers. If workers had experienced a
higher employment probability as domestic workers following
the introduction of the minimum wage legislation, this would have
suggested an increased supply of domestic workers, which in turn
would have reduced the impact of minimum wage legislation on
wages in the long run. However, employment opportunities seem
to have not responded to the minimum wage legislation in either
the short-run or in long-run.5.3. Intensity of treatment
As explained in the earlier section, the minimum wages set by
the various treatment states differed in terms of hourly rates, the
method of calculation and the tasks included. Naturally, the differ-
ence between the pre-existing wages and the stipulated minimum
wages, which deﬁnes the treatment intensity, also differed across
these states. In this section we further analyze the impact of treat-
ment intensity on our outcome variables. The treatment intensity
is most commonly quantiﬁed in terms of wage gap (WG), which
is the difference between the minimum wages and the median
wages in the pre-treatment period, as explained in Section 4.2.
Table 9 and 10 gives the wage gap estimates using both the nor-
mal and entropy balanced DiD in the short-run and long-run,
respectively. We ﬁnd that the intensity of treatment led to a posi-
tive and statistically signiﬁcant increase in log real wages for treat-
ment states in the short-run. Higher the wage gap in the treatment
states, higher were the increase in real wages. But this impact
seems to attenuate in the long-run. This result holds with the
model speciﬁcation after including all covariates and their interac-
tions as well. Similar to the earlier case, there seems to be no
impact on employment probability.
However an important point to note is that minimum wages in
each of the four treatment states have been updated since their
respective state governments issued notiﬁcation for minimum
wages to domestic workers for the ﬁrst time. In the preceding anal-
ysis we used the minimum wages as updated until September
2012. While the use of the 2012 minimum wages is relevant for
the long run intensity of treatment (as in Table 10 ), we re-run
our short run intensity of treatment by creating wage gap variable
for each of the treatment states with minimum wages notiﬁed
until the year 2010.21We also run speciﬁcations by including state
dummies and interactions (both individually and together). The
short run impact remains positive and signiﬁcant as before. Further-
more using the 2010 updated minimum wages in order to calculate
the long run intensity of treatment does not change the results.Table 4

5.4. Wage distribution analysis
Comparing the actual wages obtained by workers with the
instituted minimum wages can shed light on the enforcement
levels and mechanism of impact. Figs. 1 and 2 provide the kernel
density plots of wage distributions of early adopter state (Kar-
nataka) and late adopter states along with applicable nominal min-
imum wages. The following key observations stand out, ﬁrstly, a
signiﬁcant proportion of wages occur below the minimum wage
levels, giving evidence of imperfect compliance. Secondly, in the
short run there is a movement of the wage distribution to the right,
while the distribution of wages shows a slight shift to the left in the
long-run. This is in line with what we observed using the
difference-in-difference estimations in terms of a short-run posi-
tive impact which disappears in the long run. Moreover, these dis-
tributional graphs shows wide-spread lack of enforcement of the
legislation, which we further explore as the potential mechanism
of the observed results in the next section. Further, Fig. 3 shows
the distribution in wages of control states, which do not show
any signiﬁcant shifts over the years.
6. Possible mechanisms
This section discusses the possible mechanisms that might help
explain the observed results. The estimations suggest that there
was a strong impact on real wages in the short-run but this impact
disappears in the long run, with no signiﬁcant effect on the
employment in short and long run. There are two potential mech-
anisms that can drive the result. The ﬁrst being supply side factors,
in which the higher minimum wages in treatment states led to
increased supply of domestic sector workers in these states (from
both inter-sector and inter-state migration of workers), leading
to gradual disappearance of differential trends in wages betweentreatment and control states.22While the second mechanism deals
with enforcement, where the lack of enforcement of the legislation
leading to a gradual disappearance of any positive ‘announcement
effect’ of the legislation on wages.
To uncover which of the potential mechanisms at play we con-
duct a spatial analysis of impact of legislation. The basic intuition
being any signiﬁcant ‘supply side’ effects of treatment will be more
prominent in the districts within the control group that are closest
to treatment states. We classify the districts within the control
groups according to their distance from the treatment states. Those
control groups that fall within a 250 km distance of treatment
groups (from the state borders) were called ‘near controls’, thosefurther than this distance are classiﬁed as ‘far controls’. If the sup-
ply side effects were at play, we would observe a different trend in
‘near controls’ as opposed to ‘far controls’. While this is an arbitrary
boundary limit, the results also hold with a non-arbitrary near and
far control grouping based on contiguous boundaries.
23
Fig. 7 , traces the movement of estimated mean wages in treat-
ment groups and distance classiﬁed control groups in 2004 (61st
round), 2009 (66th round) and 2012 (68th round). As shown by
the previous empirical analyses, the mean estimated wage of the
treatment group for the 66th round signiﬁcantly rises relative to
the real wages in the control groups when compared to the pre-
treatment 61st round. The ﬁgure clearly shows that the wages in
both the control groups (far and near) are on the rise between
2009 and 2012, while the mean wages in the treatment group
seem to have stagnated.
While, Fig. 8 plots the movement of employment probability. It
reveals similar trends in employment measure across the treat-
ment, near and far controls.Table 6

[Page 11 of 20]
(66th and 68th rounds), there seems to be a secular increase in real
wages when compared to the pre-treatment round (61st round).
This however is not the case with domestic work where the actual
wages seem to be stagnating between 2009 and 2012 similar to
Fig. 7 . Hence, our spatial analysis reveal no heterogeneous effects
for any of the outcome variables for near and far controls, pointing
at limited supply side factors.
The disappearance of the positive impact on treated wages in
the long-run in comparison to control states and proxy sector
can be due to two potential mechanisms. First, the signiﬁcant
short-run effect on wages observed in 2009 for the treatmentstates had a signiﬁcant impact on the labour supply in the control
groups and proxy sectors which led them to adjust wages upwards
in order to equalize wages with treatment states in the long-run.
Second, the legislation was not effectively implemented or
enforced in the treatment states and as a result the wages in the
treatment states stagnated in the long-run, following a short-
term surge after the announcement of minimum wages, while
the wages in the control groups gradually caught up with the trea-
ted states by 2012 given the rigidity associated with the informal-
ity of the domestic work sector. The gradual catch up of wages in
the control group relative to the treatment group might be a spillFig. 1. Distribution of nominal wages and minimum wage: Karnataka.
Fig. 2. Distribution of nominal wages and minimum wage: late treatment states.R.R. Gudibande, A. Jacob / World Development 130 (2020) 104943 11
----------------------------------------

[Page 12 of 20]
over ‘numeraire’ effect of the minimum wage announcement in the
treated states ( Maloney, 2004 ).24
It is difﬁcult to delineate between these two potential mecha-
nisms due to paucity of panel data with employment history of
workers. However, evidence from the previous Section 5.2revealed
that there was no signiﬁcant impact of the legislation at the exten-
sive margin on the employment probability of domestic workers.
Further, there do not seem to be any difference in wage or employ-
ment trends between ‘far’ and ‘near’ controls, as we expect supply-
side effects to be more pronounced in ‘near’ controls. This seem to
reduce the possibility that any signiﬁcant supply-side adjustments
might have taken place as a result of the legislation.
We further study the impact of inter-state migration to treat-
ment states from control states. Unfortunately, migration details
of workers are included only in special rounds of NSS. We usethe available migration data for 2007 (64th round) to analyse the
general migration patterns of domestic workers. By 2007, Kar-
nataka had already implemented the minimum-wage law, we ﬁnd
that even in Karnataka the patterns of migration among domestic
workers followed the same pattern as the rest of the treatment
States. Tables 11 and 12provide the details on proportion of
migrant domestic workers and proxy workers (hotel and restau-
rant sector), in short-term (less than 1 year) and long-term (greater
than 1-year), for both Karnataka and control states. Here, migrants
are deﬁned as those workers who moved outside their home-
districts. It seems the proportion of migrants engaging in domestic
work is very low (less than 10 %). Out of these migrants, the major-
ity of workers are intra-state migrants both in domestic work and
proxy sector, with workers moving across state boundaries being a
minor fraction. Summarizing, the share of migrant domestic work-
ers, both intra-State and inter-State, is not signiﬁcant enough to
have any impact on state-wide wages in this sector. Additionally,
there are no signiﬁcant differences in migration particulars
between Karnataka and other states. So what impedes migration
of workers across states to take advantage of higher wages across
borders? This question was explored in detail by Kone, Liu,
Mattoo, Ozden, and Sharma (2018) , who attributes low rate of
inter-state migration in India to state-level entitlement schemes,
ranging from access to subsidized goods through the public distri-bution system to the bias for states’ own residents in access to ter-
tiary education and public sector employment. Hence, workers do
not want to move across borders in fear of loosing out of these
entitlements.
If not supply side factors, what could explain the short-run
surge and long-run stagnation of wages in treatment states? The
announcement of minimum wages in treatment states, often by
Ministers, gave the legislation a signiﬁcant media attention. In fact,
a survey conducted among employers in treatment states found
that media reports, newspapers and TV, were cited as the main
sources of information on minimum wages Neetha (2013a) . This
might have led to wage adjustment in treatment states as captured
by short-run analysis (between 2004–2009). Our analysis in Sec-
tion 5.4shows that majority of workers earned wages below the
minimum wages, hence lack of compliance was the norm. Further,plenty of qualitative evidence from the treatment states seem to
support the case for poor monitoring and implementation of the
legislation. Neetha (2013a) provides ample qualitative evidence
on weak enforcement of legislation from all the four treatment
states. Some of the key impediments to the enforcement that were
identiﬁed through interactions with labour ministry ofﬁcials,
domestic workers and union representatives ranged from the lack
of awareness about the provisions within the legislation among
workers and employers to restrictions on labour inspections at pri-
vate households. The weak enforcement of the legislation most
likely incentivized employers not to update the wages beyond
2009 allowing wages to stagnate in treatment states.
As illustrated in Section 2.2a plausible explanation for the same
can be found in Basu et al. (2010) which shows that turning a blind
eye to a minimum wage legislation by the very same government
which passed it can be an equilibrium phenomenon. The result
indicates that since credible enforcement most likely requires
costly ex-post transfer of income from employers to workers, a
government concerned only with pareto efﬁciency but not with
distribution is unable to credibly elicit efﬁciency improvements
via a minimum wage reform. Interestingly, congruent to these the-
oretical implication, in Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh, the mini-
mum wage notiﬁcation for domestic sector workers came even
with the explicit guideline that employers are exempted from
Fig. 3. Distribution of nominal wages: control states.12 R.R. Gudibande, A. Jacob / World Development 130 (2020) 104943
----------------------------------------

[Page 13 of 20]
maintaining records of employment. Also labour inspectors were
not allowed legally to inspect private households, and complaint
redressal and monitoring mechanisms were non-existent
(Neetha, 2013 ). This seems like a possible intervention by Govern-
ments to pacify employers of domestic workers, an illustration of
turning a blind eye. We ﬁnd no increase in the number of labour
inspectors in these States over the years (see Fig. 10 ), suggesting
no signiﬁcant efforts in improving of minimum wage compli-
ance.25As a result, the impact of legislation seems to have waned
off completely by 2012.
7. Robustness checks
7.1. Parallel trends
We ﬁrst test the crucial assumption of parallel trends. Fig. 4
shows the trend of average real wages in the pre-treatment period
(i.e., 1999 and 2004) and post-treatment period for both treatment
and control states.26The graph strongly supports the parallel trend
assumption, as well as the observed deviation in trends post-treatment. Fig. 5 provides similar plot for the employment measure
of probability of employment as domestic worker over 1999–2012.
We observe similar trends in employment probability in treatment
and control states both before treatment and after treatment. This
provides further evidence of lack of any supply side effects following
the implementation of the legislation.
7.2. Common support
The second assumption that MDID relies on is that of common
support, which translates to the fact that there is an adequate over-
lap of efﬁcient matches. We ﬁnd that common support assumption
holds in terms of each of our covariates and their interactions for
both our outcome variables. In addition, in all the MDID estima-
tions, the sensitivity of the common support region was checked
following methods in Black & Smith (2004); Heckman, Ichimura,
and Todd (1998b); Mizala et al. 2011 .27In addition, in all the MDIDFig. 4. Trends in estimated and real wages 1999–2012.

workers in each treatment state. This is because we do not have any information on
the size of the total informal labor workforce in each state.
26The ﬁtted values are estimated using a simple linear regression of real wages on
time and an intercept.27We use two methods to accurately determine the region of common support. First
all observations with a propensity score smaller than the minimum and larger thanthe maximum in the opposite group were deleted using the minima and maxima
criterion. This is the primary method operationalized earlier. Second, following
Heckman et al. (1998) , 5% of the observations with low density values were trimmed.
As a further robustness check we also trimmed 10% of the observations with lowdensity values, and following ( Black & Smith, 2004; Mizala, Romaguera, & Gallegos,
2011 ), we deﬁne a thick support region deﬁned by 0 :33<^pðxÞ<0:67. The results do

estimations, the balancing of the covariates between the treatment
and control groups were veriﬁed using the t-test. In order to ensure
that our results are not driven by any one particular state, we
remove one treatment state at a time and re-run our analysis and
ﬁnd that our results hold in all speciﬁcations.
7.3. Balancing test and checking for distributional shifts
As our estimation relies on propensity score matching, it is
important to verify that balancing conditions are satisﬁed by thedata and ensure the reliability of estimations. We conduct a set
of balancing tests following Girma and Görg (2007), Rosenbaum
and Rubin (1985), Smith and Todd (2005) as explained in appendix
section 2. The results of the balancing tests for the covariates in the
paper are given in Table A-13 . Across the four tests, the balancing
conditions are satisﬁed. The regression test proposed by Smith and
Todd (2005) also supports the balancing result as all the interac-
tion terms with the treatment dummy are jointly insigniﬁcant
for each of the covariates. We also check the sensitivity of propen-
sity score balancing between treatment and matched controls byFig. 9. Log Real Wages in Domestic vs Placebo Sector.

using various re-weighting schemes laid out in DiNardo, Fortin,
and Lemieux (1996), Nichols et al. (2008) , followed by joint hotell-
ing t-tests.28The results support a balanced sample across both the
treatment and control groups. We further check the robustness of
matching estimates to minor changes in the propensity score model
(Dehejia, 2005 ). The matching estimates also emerge robust to
changes in the propensity score model.
We follow the approach taken by Dinkelman and Ranchhod
(2012) to show that the shift in observable characteristics of the
domestic workers do not account for the signiﬁcant shift in wages
between 2004 and 2009. Following the same methodology as in
Dinkelman and Ranchhod (2012) appendix 2, Fig. 11 shows that
despite re-weighting the pre-treatment data with the post-
treatment distributional characteristics, the rightward shift in
wages after treatment persists in the short-run.7.4. State-time trends and non-linear marginal effects
Our diff-in-diff estimates suggests that there is a non-linear
effect of treatment between the short and the long run. Based on
the approach in Wolfers (2006) , we employ Eq. 7to estimate the
treatment effect on real wages from heterogeneity in effective
treatment years after pooling data from 1999, 2004, 2009 and
2012 survey rounds, while controlling for state-time trends.29
Fig. 6 shows estimates of non-linear marginal effects for incremental
increase in years from effective treatment. We ﬁnd that the marginal
effect from treatment in the short-run is positive and signiﬁcant
(years 1 to 3). However as the number of years increase beyond 3,
the marginal effect seems to become negative and insigniﬁcant, in
line with the main diff-in-diff results.
7.5. Placebo sector and alternate control group
We conduct further robustness check by running the exact
difference-in-difference estimations used to derive our main
results for a placebo sector. As stated in Section 6we select work-
ers in hotels and restaurants to be the placebo sector as their tasks
and even work timings are comparable to that of domestic work-
ers. If our main results hold, the difference-in-difference analysis
of the outcome variables (wages and employment) should not
show any signiﬁcant results for this placebo sector. We conduct
the normal diff-in-diff, ebalance and matching analysis and ﬁnd
that there is no statistically signiﬁcant treatment effect in the pla-
cebo sector. The diff-in-diff and ebalance results of this robustness
check is provided in Table A-3 and A-4 in the Appendix .30ThisFig. 10. Number of central labour inspectors per urban workers in treatment states.

implies that the treatment effect was not capturing any macro-level
shock that affected all similar sectors in the treatment states during
the post-treatment period. This imparts further conﬁdence in our
identiﬁcation strategy’s ability to isolate the impact of the treatment
on domestic sector workers.
We also conduct similar analysis on the probability of being
employed in hotel and restaurants. We ﬁnd no treatment effect
on the sector at the extensive margin in the short-run, however
we ﬁnd a positive treatment impact in the long-run. Had this
effect been due to any shift of workers from hotel and restaurant
sector to domestic work then the effect would have been a neg-
ative. So the positive impact could be driven by a factor unre-
lated to the minimum wage effect. The results of these placebo
extensive margin analysis are included in Appendix Tables A-5
and A-6 .
In order to develop a more comparable control group, we
further restrict our control groups to untreated states that share
borders with treatment states and then re-run the analysis. The
diff-in-diff and ebalance results of this robustness check pro-
vided in Tables A-8 and A-9 in the Appendix clearly show that
after restricting the control group to the untreated border
states, we see a signiﬁcant treatment effect with similar signs
and magnitude on log real wages in the short run and no sig-
niﬁcant effect in the long run.31The increase in wages in the
short run or a3estimate including the MDID results ranges
between 0.26 to 0.33, which is similar to the increase in our
main results.
7.6. Gender
Domestic work sector in India is dominated by female workers,
so we conducted a sub-sample analysis for female workers. Our
results remain similar in magnitude and in statistical signiﬁcance
for this sub-group.
7.7. State and city level heterogeneity
Implementation capacity of states could be different, which
could hamper the implementation of any law. We looked at the
NREGS implementation performance reports of the four treat-ment states. Andhra Pradesh and Rajasthan emerge as top per-
formers in terms of NREGS implementation, with Karnataka and
Bihar trailing behind ( Breman & Varinder, 2012 ). So we clubbed
together the two top-performers and repeated the analysis exclu-
sively for these two treatment states. We found that our results
did not vary from the main ﬁndings, suggesting that the mini-
mum wage law implementation did not vary signiﬁcantly in these
two states.
Further, using migration statistics from India, Imbert and Papp
(2016) show that the migration effect of NREGS on urban areas
affected mostly the male, short-term migrants who engaged in
mostly casual unskilled activities especially in construction and
manufacturing sectors. So the impact of differential implementa-
tion rates of NREGS during the initial phase of its implementation,
on domestic work sector dominated by women who tend to
migrate for long-term, would be limited.
Furthermore, to control for any differential impact due to scale
of cities, we estimate MDID short run estimates with city dummies
and the interaction terms as additional covariates (with clustered
standard errors). We create dummies for 10 big metros and include
it as additional controls in our regressions along with interaction
controls. The key results continue to hold.
327.8. Sensitivity to small number of clusters
Inference based on clustered-robust standard errors (CRSE) is
robust to both intracluster correlation and unknown heteroskedas-
ticity. However in setting such as ours where treated groups are
small in number, we check the sensitivity of the CRSE for the sta-
tistically signiﬁcant treatment effects on real wages.We employ a
Wild Restricted Efﬁcient bootstrap with weights from Webb’s six
point distribution discussed in Cameron, Gelbach, and Miller
(2008) and Roodman, Nielsen, MacKinnon, and Webb (2019) . The
last column in Table 4 gives the bootstrap p-values from the main
short run MDID estimations shown in the second column after
9999 replications. The results maintain a signiﬁcant treatment
effect on real wages in the short run. While last column in Table 6
shows an insigniﬁcant effect on real wages in the long run afterbootstrapping the results presented in second column of Table 6 .
33
8. Discussion and implications for future research
The main conclusion derived from the above analysis is that
minimum wage legislation for domestic sector workers seems to
have had a signiﬁcant positive impact in terms of real wages in
the short-run (by 2009), while there seems no evidence of signiﬁ-
cant positive impact on wages in the long-run (by 2012).
The estimated impact on log real wages is around the magni-
tude of 0.3, which translates to a 30 percent increase in real wages
approximately (in 2004 prices). This is a substantial increase in the
short run. However this impact of minimum wage legislation
becomes rather limited in the long run as the short run increase
in wages are not sustained after 2009. In fact in treatment states,
the domestic sector wages seem to have missed the secular rise
in wages observed in a close informal sector such as hotel and
restaurants across both treatment and control states. The paper
rules out the case of a supply-side adjustment as the driving factor
for this change and points at the direction of weak implementation
or enforcement of the legislation.
The paper also throws light on the question of how these min-
imum wages stood in comparison to the wage levels that existed in
these states before the implementation of the minimum wage leg-
islation. We ﬁnd that the pre-existing wages were considerably
lower than that of the introduced minimum wage. Hence, if the
minimum wage legislation was implemented properly, we would
have observed a signiﬁcant increase in real wages. The distribution
analysis revealed that majority of workers continued to get wages
lower than the minimum wages in the short and long run.
Our study suggests that legislation alone cannot make much
difference to the lives of informal sector workers such as domestic
work. A strong, transparent and efﬁcient monitoring mechanism is
crucial. Sengupta and Sen (2013) point to the fact that the mini-
mum wage laws protect the employers interests compared to that
of the domestic workers as the employers do not have to maintainregisters on wages given, nor create contracts with the domestic
workers. This certainly complicates the monitoring and enforce-
ment mechanism in this sector. Perhaps minimum wage legislation
should also make it compulsory to issue formal contracts to
domestic workers. Stronger formalization efforts need to accom-
pany these minimum wage legislation to increase the probability
of enforcement. This was the approach taken in Brazil, where min-
imum wage legislation for domestic workers was followed up by
efforts to increase formalization of the sector, especially by guaran-
teeing fundamental labor rights and mandatory registration of
labor cards of domestic workers. Subsequent to these efforts in
31The MDID results will be presented on request.
32The result tables can be presented on request.33We also estimate the bootsrap p-values for the short run wage effect in the
placebo sector as shown in Table A-11. The results remain insigniﬁcant.18 R.R. Gudibande, A. Jacob / World Development 130 (2020) 104943
----------------------------------------

[Page 19 of 20]
Brazil, between 2001 and 2009 the number of formalized domestic
workers increased by 30% in Brazil ( Gomes & Puig, 2013 ). Another
possible intervention is providing incentives for employers to com-
ply with the legislation. Incentives in terms of tax credits are used
in Belgium and France to increase compliance to regulations in
domestic work sector ( D’souza, 2010 ).
Placement agencies that recruit workers from rural areas to be
placed in urban households are emerging as key players. Regulat-
ing the work of these agencies through guidelines on placement
records and formal contracts could be a way of improving the
effective implementation of the minimum wage legislation. Fur-
ther, the Government of India has initiated a new universal identi-
ﬁcation scheme in terms of issuing biometric id cards (called
Aadhar cards) linked to bank accounts. In future, the payment of
domestic sector wages to the workers’ bank accounts could bemade mandatory, opening up further avenues to formalize this
sector.
In terms of future research, the impact of minimum wage legis-
lation on within state migration needs to be studied in more detail.
Another area for future research is the impact of union member-
ship of worker on wage bargaining.
9. Conclusion
This paper conducts an impact evaluation of the minimum
wage legislation for domestic workers in urban areas of four Indian
states. It tests the impact of the legislation at both intensive (real
wages) and extensive (employment) margins in both short-run
and in long-run. We ﬁnd that the minimum wage legislation had
positive and statistically signiﬁcant impact on real wages in the
short-run. The paper also ﬁnds a similar impact in terms of theintensity of the treatment itself, measured by wage gap. Higher
wage gap resulted in higher treatment impact in the short-run.
However, there seems no evidence of positive impact on real
wages by 2012. In the case of the probability of being employed
as a domestic worker, the legislation seems to have had no impact
in both short and long run. After considering supply side factors
including migration, the paper leans toward an absence of effective
monitoring and enforcement as the key driver of these results
based on available evidence. Qualitative evidence from the
ground-level analysis of these treatment states, ﬁnds that the leg-
islation was not accompanied by any strong enforcement and
monitoring mechanisms. As a result, the wages in treatment states
stagnated over the years, after the initial surge following the
announcement of minimum wages, while in the control groups
the wages gradually rose to catch-up with wages in treatment
states. The paper concludes with suggestions on improving
enforcement of minimum wage legislation for informal sectors
such as domestic work.

IZA Discussion Paper No. 1117 
April 2004 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
ABSTRACT 
 
The Effects of Vocational Training Programmes on the 
Duration of Unemployment in Eastern Germany 
 
This paper focuses on the effects of vocational training programmes on the duration of 
unemployment in Eastern Germany. We use in formation from administrative data of the 
Federal Employment Office. To allow for observable and possible unobservable influences 
we apply a multivariate mixed proportional hazard model. Furthermore, particular interest is 
spent on possible locking-in effects by separate estimation of in- and after-programme effects. Regarding several different programme durations our results show insignificant in- and after-programme effects for short-term programmes, insignificant in-programme and negative after-programme effects for mid-term programmes and negative in- and after-
programme effects for long-term programmes. 
 
 
 
JEL Classification: J64, J24, I28, J68 
 
Keywords: vocational training, programme evaluation, duration analysis, treatment effect 
 
 
 
Corresponding author: 
 
Reinhard Hujer 
Department of Economics and Business Administration 
University of Frankfurt 
Mertonstr.17 
60054 Frankfurt/M 
Germany 
Email: hujer@wiwi.uni-frankfurt.de
