6. Conclusions  
This study empirically  assesses  whether  there is labor reallocation  
away from automatable  employment  following  increases  in the mini- 
mum wage, and how this reallocation  aﬀects the type of employment  
held in the United States, overall,  within industries,  and for particular  
demographic  groups.  We focus speciﬁcally  on jobs that tend to be held 
by low-skilled  workers,  for which labor costs increase  the most in re- 
sponse to minimum  wage increases.  We estimate  the impact of minimum  
wage increases  on the share of low-skilled  employment  in automatable  
jobs, and on the probability  that a low-skilled  individual  working  in an 
automatable  job stays employed  (or stays employed  in the same job). 
We explore  and document  considerable  heterogeneity  in these eﬀects 
across demographic  groups,  and across industries.  The analysis  goes be- 
yond the types of workers  usually  considered  in the conventional,  long- 
standing  research  on the employment  eﬀects of minimum  wages, such 
as teenagers  –studying,  for example,  the eﬀects of minimum  wages on 
older less-skilled  workers  who are in jobs where it is easier to replace  
people with machines,  and on manufacturing  workers  in such jobs. 
Based on CPS data from 1980 to 2015, we ﬁnd that increasing  the 
minimum  wage decreases  signiﬁcantly  the share of automatable  em- 
ployment  held by low-skilled  workers.  The average  eﬀects mask sig- 
niﬁcant  heterogeneity  by industry  and demographic  group. For exam- 
ple, one striking  result is that the share in automatable  employment  
declines  rather sharply  for older workers  –a n d within manufacturing,  
most sharply  for this age group. An analysis  of individual  transitions  
from employment  to nonemployment  (or to employment  in a diﬀer- 
ent job) leads to similar overall conclusions.  The heterogeneous  adverse  
eﬀects we document  indicate  that some groups typically  ignored  in the 
minimum  wage literature  are in fact quite vulnerable  to job loss be- 
cause of automation  following  a minimum  wage increase.  At the same 
time, we ﬁnd that some of the adverse  employment  eﬀects among low- skilled workers  in automatable  jobs are oﬀset by increased  employment  
opportunities  for higher-skilled  workers,  likely because  automation  of 
low-skilled  work creates other kinds of jobs. 
Our work suggests  that sharp minimum  wage increases  in the United 
States in coming  years will shape the types of jobs held by low-skilled  
workers,  and create employment  challenges  for some of them. Given 
data limitations,  we cannot address  the permanence  of the eﬀects. How- 
ever, the decision  to use labor-saving  technology  seems likely to be rel- 
atively permanent,  especially  if –as is becoming  increasingly  common  
–minimum  wages are indexed  so that a minimum  wage increase  results 
in permanently  higher relative  costs of low-skilled  labor ( Sorkin, 2015 ). 
We have followed  the deﬁnitions  of automatable  work as provided  
by Autor and Dorn (2013) . These are very useful deﬁnitions  for a ret- 
rospective  analysis,  given that the occupations  identiﬁed  as automat-  
able are highly credible.  However,  in the future many more occupa-  
tions that employ  low-skill  workers  are on track to be automated,  even 
if they are not currently  labeled  as ‘automatable.  ’These include,  for ex- 
ample, taxi drivers,  28 cashiers,  29 and bricklayers.  30 Therefore,  it is im- 
portant  to acknowledge  that increases  in minimum  wages will give in- 
centives  for ﬁrm to adopt new technologies  that replace  workers  earlier.  
While these adoptions  undoubtedly  lead to increased  job opportunities  
for some workers  –for which we ﬁnd some evidence  –it is likely that 
there are workers  who will be displaced  that do not have the skills to do 
the new tasks. We have identiﬁed  workers  whose vulnerability  to being 
replaced  by machines  has been ampliﬁed  by minimum  wage increases.  
Such eﬀects may spread to more workers  in the future.

Minimum  wage  and unemployment  in Russia:  A new look  on an old 
constructI
Gi Khan Ten, Shun Wang∗
Xi’an Jiaotong-Liverpool  University, China
A R T I C L E  I N F O
Dataset link: Minimum Wage and Unemployme
nt in Russia: A New Look on an Old Construct (
Original data)
JEL classification:
J1
J2
J3
J6
Keywords:
Minimum  wage
Unemployment
Informality
Capital-labor  substitution
Russia A B S T R A C T
We investigate  the unemployment  effects of the minimum  wage policy in Russia, focusing  on possible  reasons 
for the heterogeneity  of the effects documented  in previous  literature.  Using region-level  data, we show that the 
policy increases  both the unemployment  rate among young workers  and the rate of informality.  We corroborate  
these findings  by leveraging  a sudden increase  in the minimum  wage in Kamchatka  as a natural experiment.  
Next, we show that the magnitude  of employment  responses  to minimum  wage changes  depends  on the 
elasticity  of capital-labor  substitution,  with stronger  effects observed  in industries  where capital and labor 
are more substitutable.  When substitution  is not feasible,  employers  respond  to the policy by hiring workers  
informally.  Consistent  with revealed  separations  and informal  recruitment,  we find limited income effects of 
the policy. These findings  highlight  the importance  of accounting  for existing production  technologies  and the 
extent of non-compliance  when raising the wage floor.
1. Introduction
The minimum  wage continues  to be a controversial  policy tool. 
Some studies show that the policy reduces  income  inequality  by raising 
the bottom  tail of the income  distribution  while the disemployment  
effect is either absent or negligible  (e.g., Katz and Krueger , 1992 ; Dube 
et al., 2010 ; Draca et al., 2011 ; Giuliano , 2013 ; Cengiz et al., 2019 ). 
Other studies show that higher labor costs destroy  jobs; therefore,  the 
minimum  wage policy potentially  harms rather than protects  workers  
(e.g., Neumark  and Wascher , 2010 ; Meer and West , 2016 ; Clemens  and 
Wither , 2019 ). A nascent  strand of literature  shows that the minimum  
wage could even have a positive  impact on employment.  In a perfectly  
competitive  labor market,  the elasticity  of labor demand  with respect  
to the minimum  wage is non-positive.  However,  higher labor-market  
concentration,  with monopsony  being an extreme  case, can result in 
increased  employment  following  a minimum  wage hike. For example,  
IThe authors would like to thank Sushanta  Mallick (Editor),  the Associate  Editor who handled  this manuscript  as an anonymous  referee, and one anonymous  
referee for their valuable  feedback.  We are also grateful to the participants  of the 15th Western  Economic  Association  International  Conference  (Tokyo),  the 
16th International  Symposium  on Human Capital and Labor Markets  Conference  (Beijing),  and seminar  attendees  at Xi ’an Jiaotong-Liverpool  University  and the 
KDI School of Public Policy and Management  for their helpful comments  and suggestions.  Gi Khan Ten gratefully  acknowledges  financial  support from the Bisa 
Research  Grant provided  by Keimyung  University  in 2022 (Project  No. 20220254)
∗Corresponding  author.
E-mail address: shun.wang@xjtlu.edu.cn  (S. Wang) .
1Studies also show that labor-market  concentration  affects wages directly (e.g., Bassanini  et al., 2024 ) and moderates  the impact of minimum  wages on 
self-employment  (e.g., Glasner,  2021).Azar et al. (2024 ) show that employment  responds  positively  to a 
higher minimum  wage in U.S. counties  characterized  by sufficiently  
high labor-market  concentration.1
In addition  to labor-market  concentration,  two additional  forces — 
the focus of this paper — may moderate  the effect of the minimum  
wage on unemployment.  First, the existence  of an informal  labor sector 
can act as a buffer, allowing  firms to bypass the wage floor by em-
ploying  workers  off the books. A key feature of such employment  is its 
invisibility  to local legislators,  which allows firms to retain workers  by 
paying below the minimum  wage. Second,  the substitutability  between  
capital and labor, i.e., the shape of the two-input  production  isoquant,  
may influence  how firms respond  to higher labor costs. In industries  
where capital and labor are easily interchangeable,  firms may opt to 
substitute  labor with capital,  exacerbating  the disemployment  effects of 
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.econmod.2025.107086
Received  8 April 2024; Received  in revised form 22 March 2025; Accepted  23 March 2025Economic  Modelling  148 (2025)  107086  
Available  online  1 April  2025  
0264-9993/©  2025  Elsevier  B.V. All rights  are reserved,  including  those  for text and data mining,  AI training,  and similar  technologies.

[Page 2 of 15]
G.K. Ten and S. Wang
a higher wage floor. Conversely,  in sectors where capital-labor  substi-
tution is not feasible,  the minimum  wage may lead to less pronounced  
disemployment  effects.
This paper investigates  the aforementioned  possibilities  in the con-
text of the minimum  wage policy in Russia. Four key findings  emerge.  
First, the policy does not affect the overall unemployment  rate, but it 
has a small positive  impact on the unemployment  rate among workers  
under 30. Second,  the share of informally  employed  workers  responds  
positively  to a higher minimum  wage. Third, job separations  among 
young workers  are concentrated  in industries  that can substitute  capital 
for labor more easily. Fourth,  consistent  with job losses among young 
workers  and the increased  informalization  of the labor market,  the 
minimum  wage policy has minimal  capacity  to increase  household  
income.  Altogether,  these findings  suggest  that incompliance  — man-
ifested by employers’  ability to recruit workers  informally  — and 
strong complementarity  between  labor and capital may explain  the lack 
of detectable  disemployment  effects from the minimum-wage  policy 
observed  in some past studies.
We estimate  the unemployment  effects of minimum  wages by ex-
ploiting  two different  empirical  designs.  First, we fit a two-way  panel 
fixed-effects  model of the regional  unemployment  rate, accounting  
for potential  reverse  causality  between  the local minimum  wage and 
the outcome  variable.  The Russian  institutional  context  provides  a 
plausibly  valid instrumental  variable  (IV): Bodman’s  Winter Severity  
Index, which quantifies  human perception  of winter severity  (Bodman , 
1916 ). The choice of the instrument  stems from the observation  that 
labor unions bargain  for higher wages when winter ‘‘feels’’ harsher  
than in the past. Our results show that a 1% increase  in the regional  
real minimum  wage increases  the unemployment  rate among workers  
aged below 30 by 0.05 percentage  points. This estimate  aligns with 
the lower end of minimum  wage effects reported  in the literature.  To 
further validate  our findings,  we rule out obvious  channels  through  
which our proposed  instrument  may affect the regional  unemployment  
rate. Consistent  with most past studies,  our analysis  finds no impact of 
the minimum  wage on older workers  (e.g., Portugal  and Cardoso , 2006 ; 
Neumark  et al., 2014 ).
We substantiate  these findings  by exploiting  a sizable (63%) in-
crease in the minimum  wage in the Kamchatka  region, following  the 
long tradition  of investigating  the unemployment  effects of the min-
imum wage policy in quasi-experimental  frameworks.2 We leverage  
this unexpected  minimum  wage increase  in Kamchatka,  comparing  its 
employment  trends with those in the geographically  adjacent  control  
region: Chukotka.  Our findings  suggest  that workers  younger  than 30 
faced a three-percentage-point  higher probability  of unemployment  
following  the 63% increase  in the local minimum  wage. Differently  
put, a 1% increase  in Kamchatka’s  minimum  wage increased  the unem-
ployment  rate among young workers  by approximately  0.05 percentage  
points, a result strikingly  comparable  to that obtained  from the region-
level data. Additionally,  we show that workers  in Kamchatka  were 
more likely to be employed  informally  after the wage floor was raised.
We next examine  cross-industry  heterogeneity  in the employment  
effects of the minimum  wage among youth. Our analysis  shows that 
younger  workers  are more likely to face separations  in industries  
where capital and labor are more easily substitutable.  These findings  
align with one of the Hicks–Marshall  laws of derived  demand,  which 
predicts  that the wage elasticity  of labor demand  is higher when 
other production  inputs can replace  workers  (Allen , 1938 ; Hamermesh , 
1993 ). Furthermore,  industries  with little or no employment  declines  
in response  to the minimum  wage hike tend to employ  more workers  
informally.  These results suggest  that employers’  ability to substitute  
2Kamchatka,  located in Russia’s  Far East, is known for its remote, sparsely  
populated  terrain and geographic  isolation  from much of the country.  As 
detailed  in Section 3, it has a geographically  adjacent  region that serves as 
a natural candidate  for the comparison  group.capital for labor and hire workers  off the books are two key factors 
moderating  the employment  effects of the minimum  wage policy.
Finally,  we assess whether  the Russian  minimum  wage policy aids 
the bottom  tail of the country’s  income  distribution  by replicating  
Dube’s (2019) analysis  of U.S. data. Our results show that the policy’s  
capability  to aid economically  disadvantaged  families  in Russia is, at 
best, limited.  Job losses and informal  recruitment  are two revealed  
labor-market  responses  that limit the minimum  wage policy’s  ability 
to raise the incomes  of the poorest.
Our findings  contribute  to several strands  of minimum  wage liter-
ature. First, they help explain  the disparities  in estimated  employment  
effects across generations  of studies.  For example,  Cengiz et al. (2019 ) 
utilize a long panel of U.S. states and report no overall employment  
effects, while Harasztosi  and Lindner  (2019 ) document  minimal  em-
ployment  effects in Hungary.  These findings  differ from earlier studies 
that suggest  higher minimum  wages harm employment  (e.g., Sabia 
et al., 2012 ; Neumark  et al., 2014 ). While such disparities  are often 
attributed  to differences  in empirical  specifications  (e.g., Allegretto  
et al., 2011 , 2017 ), our results suggest  that cross-country  and tem-
poral differences  in labor-market  characteristics,  such as capital-labor  
substitutability  and informality,  also play a significant  role.
Second,  we contribute  to the literature  on firms’ adjustments  to 
higher minimum  wages. In their comprehensive  review,  Dube and Lind-
ner (2024 ) discuss various  adjustments  highlighted  in the literature,  
including  reductions  in fringe benefits,  firm exit, price increases,  input 
cost reductions,  and profit declines.  In this regard,  the most relevant  
studies to our paper examine  changes  in capital investments  in response  
to higher wages (Chen , 2019 ; Harasztosi  and Lindner , 2019 ; Hau et al., 
2020 ; Baek et al., 2021 ). Relatedly,  Lordan and Neumark  (2018 ) show 
that automatable  jobs are particularly  vulnerable  to minimum  wage 
hikes. However,  some studies report either no effect or the opposite  
finding  (e.g., Haepp and Lin, 2017 ; Gustafson  and Kotter , 2018 ). Our 
results suggest  that these discrepancies  can be partly explained  by 
industry-level  differences  in production  isoquants.
Finally,  our results expand  on the literature  linking growing  in-
formality  as a response  to minimum  wages. Studies  show that non-
compliance  with minimum  wage laws limits the policy’s  effective-
ness in Colombia  (Pérez , 2020 ), Ecuador  (Wong , 2019 ), Honduras  
(Ham , 2018 ), and Indonesia  (Comola  and Mello , 2011 ). Our find-
ings suggest  that informal  recruitment  increases  with higher minimum  
wages, particularly  where the possibility  of capital-labor  substitution  is 
limited.
The remainder  of this paper is organized  as follows.  Section  2 
introduces  the institutional  context  and describes  the data. Section  3 
discusses  our empirical  strategies.  Section  4 presents  the unemployment  
effects of the minimum  wage. Section  5 investigates  its income  effects. 
Section  6 concludes.
2. Institutional  context  and data
2.1. Minimum  wage policy in Russia
The Russian  minimum  wage policy shares at least two features  with 
that of the United States. More specifically,  first, Russia updates  its 
wage floor regularly.  However,  federal subjects  (regions  henceforth)  
have the right to set their minimum,  which must be no lower than 
the national  level, and Fig.  1 shows the dynamics  of the monthly  
nominal  minimum  wage for full-time  workers  by region and month 
between  2009 and 2012 (83 regions).  Second,  with the exception  of 
seven regions,  the Russian  minimum  wage does not vary within a 
given region in a given period.3 In six of the seven exceptional  cases, 
3There are 26 regions that have the national  minimum  wage above the 
national  one at least at one point in time within our study period. Figure 
A1 of the Online Appendix  A shows the dynamics  of minimum  wage in four 
categories  of regions,  with the first (the last) category  having the highest 
(lowest)  level of the average minimum  wage in our study period.Economic  Modelling  148 (2025)  107086  
2 
----------------------------------------

[Page 3 of 15]
G.K. Ten and S. Wang
Fig. 1. Nominal minimum  wage, by region.
Notes: The figure illustrates  the dynamics  of the natural logarithm  of nominal monthly full-time equivalent  minimum  wages by month from January 2009 to December  2012.
the difference  is either between  the public and private sectors (Altai 
Krai, Kurgan  Oblast, Kursk Oblast, Tula Oblast, and Tyumen  Oblast)  or 
among the public, private,  and agricultural  sectors (Volgograd  Oblast).  
Among  these six regions,  the largest wage difference  between  public 
and private sector workers  is 45%, to the detriment  of the public sector 
(Tula Oblast, in 2012). In the remaining  region, Karelia,  the minimum  
wage varies across cities, favoring  workers  in colder areas.
We obtain data on the regional  minimum  wage from publicly  avail-
able trilateral  agreements  involving  the government,  labor unions,  and 
employers’  associations.  For the aforementioned  seven regions,  where 
the minimum  wage varies by sectors and/or by cities, we proceed  as 
follows.  In six regions  with sector-specific  wage floors, we construct  
a weighted  average  minimum  wage, using the share of workers  in 
each sector as weights.  In the region with city-specific  wage floors, 
we weight the minimum  wage by the share of the population  in each 
city. The data needed  to construct  sectoral  or city-level  weights  is 
publicly  available  from the Russian  Federal  Statistics  Service.  Finally,  
we collapse  the minimum  wages to the region-year  level.
To understand  the relative  size of the Russian  minimum  wage, 
it is useful to compare  the minimum-to-average  wage ratio in the 
country  — a variant  of the Kaitz index — with its values observed  in 
countries  frequently  appearing  in the literature.  For example,  in 2012, 
the Russian  Kaitz index was 0.28.4 This value is slightly  higher than 
that of the United States (0.27) during the same period,  as reported  by 
the International  Labor Organization,  but considerably  lower than in 
other countries  frequently  mentioned  in the minimum  wage literature,  
such as Canada  (0.4), Hungary  (0.4), and the United Kingdom  (0.39). 
In the following  section,  we describe  three key features  of the dynamics  
of minimum  wages that are relevant  to our econometric  identification:  
(i) substantial  cross-regional  differences  in minimum  wage levels; (ii) 
4The authors’  calculations  using the data obtained  from the Federal 
Statistics  Service.a tendency  for colder regions  to have higher wage floors, on average;  
and (iii) the introduction  of new minimum  wages typically  occurring  
in the first quarter  of the year.
First, as illustrated  in Fig.  1, significant  disparities  exist in minimum  
wage levels across regions.  This heterogeneity  is, in part, a result of 
varying  living costs among regions.  For instance,  Moscow,  known as the 
most expensive  city in Russia, has the highest  wage floor. On average,  it 
surpasses  the federal minimum  wage by 4.2 sample standard  deviations  
over the entire study period.
Second,  besides  the living cost, another  important  factor influencing  
the variations  in both the level and growth  of regional  minimum  wages 
is the local winter weather.  Specifically,  in colder regions,  workers  
have historically  received  higher minimum  wages. This phenomenon  
can be attributed  to the past implementation  of the Northern  Multiplier  
policy, designed  to compensate  individuals  for working  under extreme  
weather  conditions.  Consequently,  in several regions,  particularly  in 
the North and Far East, employers  were previously  mandated  to pro-
vide minimum  wages equal to the state-level  wage floor multiplied  
by a region-specific  multiplier.  This multiplier  ranged from 1.15 to 2 
and remained  in effect until 2007. As a result of the historical  pres-
ence of the Northern  Multiplier,  the minimum  wage in some regions  
consistently  exceeded  the national  level. For example,  three regions  
with wage floors just below Moscow’s  are Yamalo-Nenets,  Nenets,  and 
Khanty-Mansiysk  Autonomous  Okrugs,  all of which belong to Northern  
Russia.
Region-specific  minimum  wages are established  through  trilateral  
negotiations  involving  government  representatives,  labor unions,  and 
employers’  associations.  For instance,  business  representatives  may 
propose  that the government  refrain from increasing  the minimum  
wage if the local unemployment  rate is on the rise in a particular  region. 
Conversely,  labor unions advocate  for supporting  workers  during severe 
winter conditions,  even in areas where the Northern  Multiplier  has 
never been applied  (e.g., Southern  Russia).  The link between  win-
ter severity  and the proposed  minimum  wage level is mediated  by Economic  Modelling  148 (2025)  107086  
3 
----------------------------------------

[Page 4 of 15]
G.K. Ten and S. Wang
expectations  of rising living costs and the desire to provide  moral 
compensation  for harsh working  conditions.  Consequently,  one may 
observe  an increase  in wage floors in certain regions  where no other 
economic  factors,  such as steeply rising current  consumer  prices or a 
low recent unemployment  rate, could justify high minimum  wages.5 
This observation  is central to our baseline  analysis,  which we elaborate  
on in Section  3.
Lastly, as Fig.  1 shows, new minimum  wages are typically  intro-
duced at the beginning  of the year. This observation  likely makes the 
introduction  of the new minimum  wage in the middle of the year less 
anticipated  by employers.  Based on this conjecture,  as a robustness  
check, we investigate  whether  unemployment  responds  to a plausibly  
unexpected  sharp minimum  wage increase  in Kamchatka,  which is 
one of the Russian  regions  that suddenly  increased  its wage floor by 
about 63% in the middle of the year—we  elaborate  further on this in 
Section  3.2.
2.2. Data
Regional  Characteristics .—Our investigation  begins with an analysis  
of regional  unemployment  rates. We obtain regional  indicators,  includ-
ing the overall unemployment  rate, age-specific  unemployment  rates 
(categorized  into three age groups:  15–19, 20–29, and 30+), and the 
proportion  of the labor force engaged  in informal  employment,  from 
the ‘‘Regional  statistics’’  section of the Russian  Federal  Statistics  Ser-
vice’s portal. The Russian  Federal  Statistics  Service  defines  individuals  
working  in the informal  sector as those employed  during the reporting  
period in an informal  enterprise.  An informal  enterprise  is defined  as 
an organization  that produces  goods and services  for market sale but 
lacks the legal status of a corporate  entity. The key feature of informal  
employment  relevant  to our study is its operation  outside  official 
oversight.  Consequently,  the minimum  wage floor is, in principle,  not 
binding  in such labor arrangements.
We also collect regional  data on real GDP per capita, consumer  
price index, working-age  population,  health-related  metrics  (such as 
the regional  pupil-to-doctor  ratio and per capita disease  rates), net 
migration  inflow, agricultural  output normalized  by GDP, electricity  
production,  and average  household  utility expenses  from the same 
data source.  Additionally,  we retrieve  nominal  minimum  wages from 
trilateral  agreements  involving  labor unions,  employers’  associations,  
and the government.  Finally,  we obtain data on temperature  and wind 
speed from the Hydrometeorological  Centre of Russia. Our dataset  
contains  the full set of variables  for the years 2009 to 2012. Table  1 
presents  summary  statistics.
To investigate  the relationship  between  industry-level  elasticity  of 
substitution  and the employment  effects of the minimum  wage, we 
collect additional  data on employment  indicators  (including  youth 
and informal  employment),  capital investments,  average  wages, and 
value-added  per worker  for each region-industry-year  cell from the 
same state’s statistics  service.  Additionally,  we use two survey datasets,  
which are publicly  available  from the ‘‘Federal  Statistical  Surveys  on 
Socio-Demographic  Issues’’ section of the Russian  Federal  Statistics  
Service’s  portal, as detailed  below.
Russian  Labor Force Survey, 2010–2013 .—To test the robustness  of 
our baseline  findings  from the regional  data, we conduct  a further 
investigation  of one region’s  higher minimum  wage introduction  using 
the Russian  Labor Force Survey (RLFS).  Conducted  by the Russian  
State Statistics,  the RLFS surveys  approximately  70,000 people from

and Ivanovo  Oblast in the Central Federal District.  None of these regions,  due 
to their geographic  location,  has ever been subject to the Northern  Multiplier  
policy, yet their minimum  wages have consistently  remained  above the federal

Russian  regions.  The number  of surveyed  individuals  varies, covering  
45,000 families  in 2014 and up to 160,000  in 2017.
3. Empirical  strategy
We begin by examining  the response  of the overall and age-specific  
unemployment  rates to changes  in the minimum  wage. Additionally,  we 
include  informal  employment  as an outcome  variable,  given its role as 
a source of income  for individuals  unable to secure formal employment  
(Porta and Shleifer , 2008 ; Comola  and Mello , 2011 ). Furthermore,  we 
investigate  whether  the employment  impact of the minimum  wage pol-
icy varies with the industry-specific  elasticity  of substitution  between  
capital and labor. Finally,  we assess the implications  of the policy for 
household  income.
3.1. Region-level  analysis
Our baseline  model leverages  the region-year  panel dataset  de-
scribed  in the previous  section.  We estimate  the following  two-way  
fixed-effects  model: 
𝑦𝑖𝑡=𝛽log𝑀𝑊𝑖𝑡+𝑋′
𝑖𝑡𝜌+𝜗𝑖+𝜏𝑡+𝑢𝑖𝑡, (1)
where 𝑖 and 𝑡 index regions  and years, respectively.  The outcome  
variable,  𝑦𝑖𝑡, represents  one of the following:  (i) the annual average  
overall unemployment  rate, (ii) age-specific  unemployment  rate (with 
age groups 15–19, 20–29, and 30+), or (iii) the informality  rate, 
defined  as the proportion  of the labor force employed  informally.Economic  Modelling  148 (2025)  107086  
4 
----------------------------------------

[Page 5 of 15]
G.K. Ten and S. Wang
The primary  regressor,  log𝑀𝑊𝑖𝑡, is the natural  logarithm  of the 
annual average  real minimum  wage. 𝑋′
𝑖𝑡 is a vector of control  variables,  
𝜗𝑖 is the region fixed effect, 𝜏𝑡 is the year fixed effect, and 𝑢𝑖𝑡 is the 
error term. Consistent  with prior literature,  our baseline  specification  
includes  control  variables  such as the regional  Consumer  Price Index 
(CPI), the natural  logarithm  of regional  GDP per capita, and the natural  
logarithm  of the working-age  population  (Burkhauser  et al., 2000 ; Dube 
et al., 2010 ; Meer and West , 2016 ).
A potential  concern  with the OLS estimation  of Eq.  (1) is reverse  
causality.  It is unlikely  that regional  legislators  would raise the local 
minimum  wage if the local unemployment  rate is already  high. To 
address  this concern,  we employ  an instrumental  variable  for our key 
regressor,  log𝑀𝑊𝑖𝑡. Our primary  instrument  is the regional  average  
Winter Severity  Index for the three months  preceding  each March of 
a given year. For instance,  in the case of a given region observed  in the 
year 2009, we assign the value of the Winter Severity  Index averaged  
over December  2008, January  2009, and February  2009.
One of the earliest  measurements  of winter severity  was developed  
by the Swedish  scientist  Gösta Bodman.  In his summary  of the research  
expedition  to the South Pole (1901–1903),  Bodman  (1916 ) quantified  
the subjective  human perception  of winter severity  with the following  
equation,  now known as the Bodman  index: 
𝑆= (1 − 0.04 ×𝑇) × (1 + 0.27 ×𝑉), (2)
where 𝑆 denotes  the Bodman  index, 𝑇 represents  the temperature  
measured  on the Celsius scale (◦𝐶), and 𝑉 is the wind speed in meters 
per second (m/s). Higher values of 𝑆 indicate  a worse perception  of 
winter.  The larger coefficient  of 𝑉 (0.27) compared  to that of 𝑇 (0.04) 
aligns with Bodman’s  rationale,  which emphasizes  that wind speed 
carries greater  weight than temperature  in determining  the human 
perception  of coldness.  This is because  wind speed can lead to breathing  
difficulties,  skin damage,  and mechanical  pressure  on the human body. 
For instance,  if the temperature  is −25◦𝐶 and the wind speed is 1 m/s, 
the Bodman  index value is equal to 2.54. This value is nearly equivalent  
to a situation  where the temperature  is −5◦𝐶 and the wind speed is 
4.1 m/s.
The Bodman  index is a good candidate  for a valid instrumental  
variable  for the minimum  wage if it affects the level of minimum  wages 
(relevance)  while having no direct impact on the regional  unemploy-
ment rates (exclusion  restriction).  Thus, we first discuss the first-stage  
relationship  between  the regional  Bodman  index and the minimum  
wage level. We then present  our arguments  justifying  our exclusion  
restriction  assumption.
Fig.  1 shows that the minimum  wage consistently  exceeds  the 
federal floor in certain regions.  As elaborated  in Section  2.1, this 
phenomenon  finds its explanation  in the presence  of the Northern  
Multiplier.  In the North and Far East regions,  characterized  by cold 
winters,  workers  receive  higher minimum  wages irrespective  of labor 
market conditions.  Consequently,  the Northern  Multiplier  functions  as 
a region-specific  constant  wage multiplier,  which is fully absorbed  by 
region fixed effects. However,  the historical  existence  of this multiplier  
provides  a rationale  for the first-stage  causal relationship  between  
the Bodman  index and regional  minimum  wages. A worsening  per-
ception  of winter severity  equips local labor unions with bargaining  
power to advocate  for higher minimum  wages as compensation  for 
more challenging  working  conditions.  Indeed,  as detailed  in the results 
section,  consistent  with our conjecture,  our data reveal a strong and 
positive  first-stage  relationship  between  the Bodman  index and regional  
minimum  wages.
We now argue that the Bodman  index is unlikely  to have a direct 
impact on local unemployment  rates. Fig.  2 displays  the distribution  
of the OLS residuals  of the Bodman  index in 2012, the most recent 
cross-section  in our dataset.  These residuals  are obtained  after re-
gressing  the Bodman  index on region and year fixed effects using all 
regions  observed  from 2009 to 2012. The resulting  map suggests  that, 
once we account  for regional  time-invariant  characteristics  (such as geographic  location  and proximity  to water bodies)  and common  year-
specific  shocks,  the remaining  variation  in the index appears  to be 
nearly random.  Although  higher net levels of the Bodman  index are 
primarily  concentrated  in the northern  part of Russia, changes  within 
regions  do not seem to depend  on the region’s  geographic  location.  
Additionally,  we examine  a list of potential  factors that might mediate  
the observed  relationship  between  our IV and the unemployment  rate: 
regional  health indicators  (measured  as the population-to-doctor  ratio 
and the number  of registered  diseases  per 1,000 people),  net migration  
inflow per 10,000 people,  average  household  utility expenses,  labor 
force participation  rate, agricultural  productivity  index (measured  as 
agricultural  output over GDP), and electricity  production  (measured  in 
billions  of kWh). We document  that none of the indicators  mentioned  
above is correlated  with the Bodman  index, lending  further support  to 
our exclusion  restriction  assumption.
To formally  test the exclusion  restriction,  we introduce  an addi-
tional IV borrowed  from the existing  literature:  the mean of mini-
mum wages in geographically  adjacent  regions  (Neumark  and Wascher , 
1992 ; Rybczynski  and Sen, 2018 ). The underlying  rationale  is that 
local legislators  are likely influenced  by minimum  wage policies  in 
neighboring  regions.  While passing  the overidentification  test does not 
prove that the Bodman  index is excluded  from Eq.  (1), we interpret  the 
absence  of a statistically  significant  correlation  between  the IVs and the 
error term—as  is the case with our findings—as  additional  evidence  
supporting  the validity  of the exclusion  restriction  assumption.
3.2. A natural experiment  in the Kamchatka  region
Our analysis  of the regional  panel data heavily  relies on assumptions  
regarding  the validity  of our IV, and we provide  a range of diagnostic  
tests to assess their plausibility.  To further corroborate  our baseline  
findings,  we follow a well-established  tradition  of investigating  the 
employment  effects of minimum  wages in quasi-experimental  settings.
An ideal natural  experiment  would supply a pair of regions  that 
would have had parallel  employment  trends had one of them not 
introduced  a higher minimum  wage. With this in mind, we pick our 
‘‘treated’’  and ‘‘control’’  regions  that satisfy the following  criteria:
1.The minimum  wage increase  must be sizable so that possible  em-
ployment  effects are more likely to be detectable.  This criterion  
excludes  those cases in which regions  simply adjust local wage 
floors to inflation.
2.The intervention  must occur outside  of the first calendar  quarter.  
This condition  decreases  the likelihood  of policy anticipation  on 
the employers’  side, as in most cases, new minimum  wages are 
introduced  in the first quarter  of the year.
3.The initial minimum  wage in the ‘‘treated’’  region should follow 
the federal minimum,  as regions  with a long tradition  of higher 
minimum  wages are less likely to have labor market outcomes  
comparable  to those that follow the state’s wage floor.
In June 2012, the local minimum  wage rose from 4,611 RUB 
(Federal  Minimum  Wage) to 7,500 RUB in the Kamchatka  region. 
As shown in Fig.  1, the timing and magnitude  of this increase  are 
highly unusual.  First, most other regions  typically  update their local 
minimum  wages during the first calendar  quarter.  Second,  prior to June 
2012, Kamchatka  had consistently  aligned  its minimum  wage with the 
federal floor. The steep mid-year  deviation  from the federal minimum,  
as depicted  in Fig.  1, is nearly unprecedented.  These factors make it 
plausible  that Kamchatkan  employers  did not anticipate  this policy 
change.  Chukotka,  which is the only neighboring  region of Kamchatka,  
supplies  a natural  comparison  unit, as it is geographically  adjacent  Economic  Modelling  148 (2025)  107086  
5 
----------------------------------------

[Page 6 of 15]
G.K. Ten and S. Wang
Fig. 2. Geography  of Bodman index.
Notes: The figure plots the residuals  (in year 2012) resulting from regressing  the Bodman index on region and year fixed effects. Darker zones indicate higher (residual)  winter 
severity.
and strictly follows  the state’s wage floor throughout  the entire study 
period.6
It is natural  to wonder  about the possible  forces driving  the unusual  
minimum  wage increase  in Kamchatka.  Based on official statistics  
underlying  our data, it is unlikely  that this new wage floor was driven 
by favorable  macroeconomic  conditions.  The increase  occurred  in June 
2012. However,  in 2011, Kamchatka  ranked 63rd out of 83 regions  in 
terms of real GDP growth.  In the same year, the region ranked 58th 
for unemployment  and 49th for the consumer  price index. Thus, the 
large minimum  wage increase  was not preceded  by booming  economic  
growth,  exceptionally  low unemployment,  or a rapid rise in prices. 
Moreover,  regions  typically  update the local minimum  wage in the first 
quarter  of the year to account  for local macroeconomic  factors,  such as 
rising consumer  prices. This was not the case for Kamchatka  in 2012, 
where the new wage floor occurred  in June.
One probable  force behind the minimum  wage increase  might be 
the unexpected  appointment  of a new governor  in Kamchatka  in Febru-
ary 2011, Vladimir  Ilyukhin.  His appointment  followed  the voluntary  
resignation  of the former governor,  Alexey Kuzmitsky,  who had gov-
erned the region from July 2007 until February  2011, nearly a year 
less than the typical five-year  term. We were unable to retrieve  the 
official reason for the former governor’s  resignation  from the Kremlin’s  
website  archives.  However,  the most important  concern  is whether  
the appointment  of the new regional  administration  in early 2011 
led to employers  adjusting  their workforce  in anticipation  of the new 
minimum  wage policy—or  some other policy affecting  the local labor 
market.  Fortunately,  this can be tested with our data: as we show in the 
results section,  neither  unemployment  nor informality  rates responded  
to the ‘‘placebo’’  minimum  wage assigned  to 2011, the year of the new 
governor’s  appointment.  This finding  lends support  to the possibility  
that there was no precautionary  workforce  adjustment.
We utilize a subsample  of workers  from the two regions  mentioned  
above that is available  in RLFS 2010–2013.  Considering  the past ob-
servations  that the unemployment  response  to minimum  wages varies 
by workforce  age group, we divide our sample into the following  two

failed to find such evidence.  These findings  suggest that it is the first—the

3.3. Industry-specific  employment  responses  to the minimum  wage policy
Given that the variation  of estimated  employment  effects of the min-
imum wage in the literature,  it is natural  to consider  the characteristics  
of a given labor market that policymakers  should pay close attention  
to when introducing  a new wage floor. In this paper, we argue that 
the substitutability  of capital for labor — which likely varies across 
countries  and within a given country  across industries  — is one labor-
market characteristic  that helps predict whether  raising the minimum  
wage will result in layoffs.  This insight comes from the theoretical  
works by Allen (1938 ) and Hamermesh  (1993 ), which show that la-
bor demand’s  wage elasticity  depends  upon the substitution  elasticity  
between  capital and labor. More specifically,  assuming  that (i) a given 
industry  employs  capital (𝐾) and labor (𝐿) to produce  output (𝑌); (ii) 
the inputs are transformed  into the output by a constant  elasticity  of 
substitution  production  function;  and (iii) in equilibrium,  the market 
for the final good clears, Allen (1938 ) shows that the wage elasticity  of 
labor demand  (𝜖𝐿
𝑤) can be expressed  as follows:  
𝜖𝐿
𝑤=𝑤𝐿
𝑌𝑝𝜖𝑌
𝑝−𝑟𝐾
𝑌𝑝𝜎, (7)
where 𝑤 and 𝑟 denote the price of labor and capital,  respectively;  𝑝 is 
the market price of the good 𝑌; 𝜖𝑌
𝑝 is the price elasticity  of demand;  
and 𝜎 is the elasticity  of substitution  between  capital and labor.
As can be seen from Eq.  (7), the magnitude  of employment  loss 
triggered  by raising wages depends  upon two parameters.  First, a 
higher price elasticity  of demand  for the final good (𝜖𝑌
𝑝) results in a 
larger loss of workers.  Second,  the substitutability  between  capital and 
labor — characterized  by the value of 𝜎 — matters.  As the elasticity  
of substitution  converges  to zero (𝜎→0), the production  function  ap-
proaches  the case of perfect complements,  in which the cost-minimizing  
demand  for labor and capital is invariant  to their relative  prices. In the 
opposite  case (i.e., 𝜎→∞), the production  function  converges  to the 
case of perfect substitutes,  in which demand  for labor and capital is 
very sensitive  to their relative  prices.
Inspired  by this insight from Allen (1938 ), we show empirically  
that employment  losses induced  by higher minimum  wages are indeed 
concentrated  in industries  capable  of substituting  capital.  To do so, we 
first estimate  the industry-specific  employment  response  to minimum  
wage increases  by fitting the following  equation:  
log𝑌𝑗𝑖𝑡=𝛼log𝑀𝑊𝑖𝑡+𝐽∑
𝑗=1𝜆𝑗log𝑀𝑊𝑖𝑡×𝜓𝑗+𝑋′
𝑖𝑡𝜂+𝜅𝑗×𝑖+𝜃𝑡+𝑢𝑗𝑖𝑡,(8)
where 𝑗, 𝑖, and 𝑡 index industry,  region, and year, respectively.7 The 
outcome  variables  (log𝑌𝑗𝑖𝑡) are the following:  (i) the natural  log of 
the number  of workers  aged below 30; and (ii) the natural  log of 
the number  of workers  employed  informally.  When constructing  the 
employment  outcome  variables,  we proceed  as follows.  First, we obtain 
the total labor force size from the Russian  Federal  State Statistics  
Service.  Next, using the labor force survey described  in Section  2.2, 
we calculate  the share of the labor force aged below 30 and the share 
of informally  employed  workers  in each industry ×region ×year cell. 
Finally,  with the two pieces of information  in hand, we estimate  the 
total number  of workers  aged below 30 and those employed  informally.
The main regressors  are the natural  log of the regional  minimum  
wage log𝑀𝑊𝑖𝑡 and its interaction  with the indicator  of industry  𝑗
(log𝑀𝑊𝑖𝑡×𝜓𝑗); the term 𝑋′

which are identical  to those employed  in Eq.  (1).8𝜅𝑗×𝑖 and 𝜃𝑡 denote 
the region ×industry  and year fixed effects, respectively,  and 𝑢𝑗𝑖𝑡 is the 
error term that we cluster at the region level. We estimate  Equation  
(8) by 2SLS using the Bodman  index and its interaction  with 𝜓𝑗 as 
instruments  for the minimum  wage variable  and its interaction  with 
𝜓𝑗, respectively.  Our focus is on the estimated  value of 𝛼+𝜆𝑗, which 
informs  about the elasticity  of youth/informal  employment  with respect  
to the regional  minimum  wage in a given industry.
Next, we estimate  the industry-specific  substitutability  between  cap-
ital and labor in the following  two ways. The first approach  is to use log 
capital investments  as the outcome  in Eq.  (8); in this case, the estimated  
𝛼+𝜆𝑗 informs  about a given industry’s  ability to substitute  capital for 
labor. For example,  a negative  value 𝛼+𝜆𝑗 would imply that employers  
in the industry  in question  reduce capital investments  in response  to the 
minimum  wage increase,  which likely indicates  the complementarity  
between  capital and labor. On the other hand, a positive  value would 
indicate  that capital and labor can substitute  for each other in a given 
industry.
Another  approach  we adopt is to follow Arrow et al. (1961 ), who 
use the joint variation  of the value-added  per worker  and the real wages 
to identify  the substitution  elasticity  in each industry.  Specifically,  we 
fit the following  model: 
log𝑉𝑗
𝑖𝑡=𝜎𝑗log𝑊𝐴𝐺𝐸𝑗
𝑖𝑡+𝑋′
𝑖𝑡𝜌+𝜁𝑡+𝑡𝑐𝑖+𝜔𝑗
𝑖𝑡(9)
The outcome  variable,  log𝑉𝑗
𝑖𝑡, is the natural  log of value added per 
worker  in industry  𝑗, region 𝑖, and year 𝑡.
After obtaining  a set of estimates  for industry-specific  (i) employ-
ment responses  from Eq.  (8) and (ii) elasticities  of substitution  from Eq. 
(9), we assess whether  the two sets of point estimates  are negatively  
correlated.
4. Unemployment  effects of the Russian  minimum  wage policy:  
Results
4.1. Evidence  from the Russian  regions
Table  2 presents  the instrumental  variable  estimates  of Eq.  (1). 
Panel A displays  the second-stage  results,  while Panel B shows the 
first-stage  regression  of the log real minimum  wage on the excluded  
instrument,  the Bodman  index, and covariates.  We begin by discussing  
the results in Panel A.
Column  (1) of Panel A confirms  the findings  of recent literature,  
indicating  that the estimated  minimum  wage coefficient  is statistically  
insignificant  and numerically  close to zero in the overall unemployment  
regression.  Columns  (2) and (3) suggest  that the young workforce  is 
8We control for the regional  CPI, the natural log of the regional  GDP per 
capita, and the natural log of the working-age  population.Economic  Modelling  148 (2025)  107086  
7 
----------------------------------------

[Page 8 of 15]
G.K. Ten and S. Wang
particularly  vulnerable,  as a one percent  increase  in the real minimum  
wage results in a 0.04 and 0.053 percentage  point increase  in the 
unemployment  rates among those aged 15–19 and 20–29, respectively.  
Column  (4) implies  that the older workforce  — those aged 30 years 
and above — is unlikely  to be affected  by the minimum  wage policy. 
Column  (5) shows an increase  in the informality  rate in response  to the 
minimum  wage hike, suggesting  that the minimum  wage policy binds 
employers.  Faced with higher labor costs, companies  may hire workers  
off-the-books  to replace  formal workers.
As discussed  in the methodology  section,  we can identify  the impact 
of interest  if the Bodman  index affects the regional  minimum  wage 
while being excluded  from the unemployment  equation.  As Panel B 
shows, the Bodman  index positively  affects the regional  minimum  
wage, and the impact is precisely  estimated.  Therefore,  we must justify 
the assumption  that the minimum  wage is the only channel  through  
which our proposed  instrument  affects unemployment.
Our first strategy  is to check whether  our instrument  affects unem-
ployment  through  other channels,  such as health, migration,  agricul-
tural productivity,  energy costs, and labor force participation.  While 
this list is largely speculative,  we believe  it includes  the most plausible  
pathways  through  which the Bodman  index may affect regional  unem-
ployment.  For example,  one might argue that a worse perception  of 
winter severity  correlates  with workers’  health, influencing  their deci-
sion to participate  in the labor force. There is also the possibility  that 
workers  prefer locations  with milder winter conditions.  Additionally,  
fluctuations  in the Bodman  index may affect agricultural  output and 
electricity  costs. Finally,  economic  activity  could be related to winter 
severity  for reasons  unrelated  to workers’  health, such as productivity  
losses or caregiving  for sick dependents  (Han et al., 2023 ).
We therefore  consider  the following  regional  characteristics:  (i) 
log population-to-doctors  ratio, (ii) log number  of registered  diseases  
per 1,000 people,  (iii) net migration  inflow (per 10,000 people),  (iv) 
agricultural  output normalized  by regional  GDP, (v) log of electricity  
production  (billions  of kWh), (vi) average  household  utility expenses  
normalized  by average  household  income,  and (vii) labor force partici-
pation rate. We check whether  these regional  characteristics  respond  to 
changes  in the Bodman  index. Table B1 in Online Appendix  B presents  
the results,  showing  that none of the variables  respond  to changes  in 
the Bodman  index. This exercise  largely excludes  the possibility  that the 
Bodman  index affects the regional  unemployment  rate through  health, 
migration,  agricultural  productivity,  electricity  costs, or the regional  
labor force participation  rate. This strengthens  the assumption  that 
the regional  minimum  wage is the only channel  through  which our 
instrument  affects the local unemployment  rate.
Our second approach  to assessing  the validity  of our instrument  
is a direct statistical  test of the exclusion  restriction,  which requires  
at least two instruments  for the minimum  wage variable.  We use an 
additional  instrumental  variable,  the mean of the minimum  wages in 
geographically  bordering  regions.  Table  3 presents  the results.  Panel 
A shows that the inclusion  of the additional  instrument  does not 
significantly  alter the baseline  point estimates.  Panel B displays  the 
first-stage  regression  result. The coefficient  of the additional  instru-
ment, 𝐿𝑜𝑔(𝑎𝑣𝑒𝑟𝑎𝑔𝑒 𝑀𝑊 𝑎𝑚𝑜𝑛𝑔 𝑛𝑒𝑖𝑔ℎ𝑏𝑜𝑟𝑠 ), is positive  and statistically  
significant,  confirming  the spillover  effect from neighboring  regions.  
Moreover,  the 𝐹 statistic  of the excluded  instruments  supports  the 
strength  of the first-stage  relationship.  The last row of Table  3 reports 
the 𝑝-values of the Sargan-Hansen  𝐽 test. None of the 𝑝-values fall 
below the 10% significance  level, further supporting  our belief that the 
Bodman  index is excluded  from Eq.  (1).
4.2. Unemployment  response  in Kamchatka
In this subsection,  we present  the findings  from the natural  experi-
ment in the Kamchatka  region. Table  4 provides  summary  statistics  for 
all variables  used in the analysis,  while Table  5 presents  the regression  
results both with and without  controls.  Columns  (1)–(3)  report the results for unemployment,  and columns  (4)–(6)  report the results for 
informal  employment.
Notably,  the point estimate  of the triple interaction  term (𝑇×
𝑃𝑜𝑠𝑡 ×𝑌𝑜𝑢𝑛𝑔 ) remains  robust to the inclusion  of controls.  For instance,  
columns  (1)–(3)  suggest  that the minimum  wage hike increased  the 
probability  of unemployment  by approximately  3 percentage  points 
for individuals  under the age of 30. Columns  (4)–(6)  show that the 
probability  of informal  employment  among young workers  increased  
by 4 percentage  points following  the minimum  wage increase.
In summary,  the results in Table  5 indicate  that the introduction  
of the minimum  wage policy is associated  with a 0.03 (0.05) increase  
in the probability  of being unemployed  (employed  informally)  among 
young workers.  The coefficients  of the 𝑇×𝑃𝑜𝑠𝑡 term in columns  
(1)–(3)  suggest  that the minimum  wage policy is unlikely  to affect 
unemployment  among older workers,  consistent  with prior research  
and our previous  findings  in this section.  However,  columns  (4)–(6)  
suggest  that informality  responds  positively  to the minimum  wage even 
among more experienced  employees.
The validity  of the results reported  in Table  5 relies on the as-
sumption  that employment  trends in both regions  would have followed  
parallel  paths in the absence  of the policy intervention.  To test this 
assumption,  we exploit the fact that both regions  adhered  to the state’s 
minimum  wage floor in 2010 and 2011. We define a placebo  post-
treatment  variable,  which is set to 1 for the year 2011 and 0 for 
2010. We then substitute  the term 𝑃𝑜𝑠𝑡 with this placebo  treatment  
in Eq.  (6) and estimate  the resulting  model, with the results reported  
in Table  6. The findings  suggest  that the two regions  do not exhibit 
statistically  significant  differences  in unemployment  trends during the 
pre-treatment  period.  This result further supports  the validity  of the 
proposed  quasi-experimental  design.
Our findings  from the Kamchatka  region are largely consistent  with 
the benchmark  result presented  in Section  4.1. The regional  panel data 
estimate  suggests  that a one-percentage-point  increase  in the minimum  
wage raises the local unemployment  rate among workers  aged below 30 
by 0.05 percentage  points. The Kamchatka  case study indicates  that a 
63% increase  in Kamchatka’s  minimum  wage led to a three-percentage-
point higher probability  of unemployment  among workers  aged below 
30. In other words, a one-percent  increase  in Kamchatka’s  minimum  
wage raised the share of unemployed  youth by 0.05 percentage  points, 
which is consistent  with the baseline  estimate  from the regional  panel 
data.
4.3. Industry-specific  employment  response  to the minimum  wage policy
Columns  (1) and (2) of Table  7 present  estimates  of industry-
specific  responses  of the number  of young workers  and the number  of 
workers  employed  informally,  respectively,  to changes  in the minimum  
wage. The results indicate  that, in most industries,  an increase  in the 
minimum  wage leads to a reduction  in the number  of workers  aged 
below 30 and an increase  in informal  employment,  with the exceptions  
of Education  and Health.  The substitutability  between  formally  and 
informally  employed  workers  becomes  more apparent  when we plot 
the coefficients  from column  (1) of Table  7 against  those from column  
(2) in Fig.  3. Industries  that displace  fewer young workers  in response  
to the minimum  wage tend to hire more workers  informally.
Column  (3) of Table  7 presents  the estimated  response  of capital 
investments  to changes  in the minimum  wage, while Column  (4) reports 
the estimated  elasticity  of substitution  between  capital and labor for 
each sector. Due to the lack of wage data for the financial  sector, 
the corresponding  cell is left empty. We then link the industry-specific  
employment  responses  to minimum  wages (as reported  in column  1 of 
Table  7) to the results in columns  3 and 4, and illustrate  them in the 
two panels of Fig.  4.
Panel (a) of Fig.  4 plots the point estimates  from column  (1) against  
those from column  (4) of Table  7. The resulting  downward-sloping  
line illustrates  the estimated  cross-industry  average  employment  loss Economic  Modelling  148 (2025)  107086

As shown in the figure, a higher elasticity  of substitution  is associated  
with a larger (in magnitude)  employment  loss in a given industry,  
consistent  with theoretical  predictions.  Panel (b) of Fig.  4 plots the 
point estimates  from column  (1) against  those from column  (3) of 
Table  7. The pattern  is as follows:  industries  that are more capable  
of increasing  capital investments  in response  to the minimum  wage 
increase  tend to reduce their demand  for young workers,  consistent  
with the capital-labor  substitution  hypothesis  discussed  in Section  3.3.
The patterns  in Figs.  5and6 suggest  that industries  have at least 
two ways to adapt to the minimum  wage shock. First, if the produc-
tion technology  allows for substituting  capital for labor, the industry  
responds  accordingly.  This finding  aligns with the literature  on capital 
Fig. 3. Substitution  between young and informally  employed  workers.
Notes: The unit of observation  is industry.  The 𝑦-axis (and 𝑥-axis) shows the estimated

investment  responses  to minimum  wage increases  (Hau et al., 2020 ; 
Baek et al., 2021 ). Second,  our results indicate  that informal  recruit-
ment is another  means of adjusting  to higher labor costs: Employers  
are more likely to hire workers  informally  when facing an increased  
minimum  wage.
These results raise questions  about the effectiveness  of the Russian  
minimum  wage policy as a tool for alleviating  poverty.  Job losses 
among young workers  and the informalization  of the labor market due 
to minimum  wage increases  may limit the policy’s  ability to effectively  
assist the poor.
4.4. Who are informally  employed?
A substantial  portion  of our analysis  is dedicated  to investigating  
the implications  of the Russian  minimum  wage policy for informal  
employment.  The key feature of informal  employment  relevant  to our 
analysis  is its invisibility  to legislators,  meaning  the minimum  wage 
does not bind for such workers.  In this section,  we provide  descriptive  
characteristics  of informally  employed  workers  using the SIPP data 
described  in Section  2.9 We first examine  the proportion  of individuals

To study the share of informal  workers  in various  age and education

The outcome  variable  is an indicator  of informal  employment  for 
individual  𝑖 observed  in region 𝑟 in year 𝑡 (1 for employed  informally  
and 0 for formally  employed).  The term 𝑎𝑔𝑒 𝑔𝑟𝑜𝑢𝑝𝑖𝑟𝑡 is an indicator  
for one of nine age groups:  [20,25), [25,30), . . . , [55,60), and 60+.10 
The omitted  group consists  of workers  aged 15 to 19 years. Similarly,  
𝑒𝑑𝑢𝑐𝑖𝑟𝑡 is an indicator  for one of five education  groups:  college (or 
higher),  incomplete  college,  secondary  professional,  secondary  general,  
and incomplete  secondary.  The omitted  group comprises  individuals  
without  any secondary  education.  We also control  for a vector of 
covariates,  𝑋′
𝑖𝑟𝑡, including  marital  status, urban-area  dummy,  gender,  
and an indicator  for having at least one child under 18. Additionally,  we 
10The notation  [𝑎,𝑏) represents  a half-open  interval,  indicating  a range of 
values from 𝑎 (inclusive)  to 𝑏 (exclusive).control  for region-year  fixed effects, 𝜃𝑟×𝑡, absorbing  region-level  shocks,  
including  the minimum  wage. 𝑢𝑖𝑟𝑡 is the error term clustered  at the 
region level. We fit Equation  (10) using the sampling  weights  available  
in the SIPP data.
The estimates  of 𝛼𝑎 (𝜂𝑒) capture  the change  in the proportion  of 
individuals  employed  informally  relative  to the omitted  group, which 
comprises  individuals  aged 15 to 19 years (without  any secondary  
education).  We report two sets of parameter  estimates:  (i) Unadjusted,  
obtained  without  any controls,  and (ii) those obtained  after including  
the full set of controls.
Fig.  5 presents  the results by age group. We observe  that, relative  to 
individuals  aged 15 to 19 years, each older age group has a lower pro-
portion  of informally  employed  individuals.  This result holds regardless  
of the deployment  of controls.  Moreover,  an overall negative  trend is 
evident  as we move to older worker  groups,  indicating  that, conditional  
on having a job, the likelihood  of being employed  informally  decreases  
with age.
Fig.  6 displays  the proportion  of employed  individuals  with informal  
jobs by education  group. It is clear that higher educational  attainment  
is negatively  associated  with the likelihood  of having an informal  job 
(as opposed  to formal employment).  The point estimates  show little 
difference  between  the unadjusted  and fully saturated  models.
In summary,  informally  employed  workers  are, on average,  (i) 
younger  and (ii) less educated  compared  to their formally  employed  Economic  Modelling  148 (2025)  107086

counterparts.  We now proceed  with a descriptive  examination  of the 
implications  of informal  employment  for annual earnings  by fitting the 
following  model: 
𝐿𝑜𝑔(𝐴𝑛𝑛𝑢𝑎𝑙 𝑒𝑎𝑟𝑛𝑖𝑛𝑔𝑠𝑖𝑟𝑡) =𝜏𝐼𝑛𝑓𝑜𝑟𝑚𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑟𝑡+𝑋′
𝑖𝑟𝑡𝜙+𝜗𝑟×𝑡+𝑣𝑖𝑟𝑡. (11)
The outcome  variable  is the natural  log of annual earned income  
for individual  𝑖 observed  in region 𝑟 in year 𝑡. The main regressor  is 
an indicator  of informal  employment,  𝐼𝑛𝑓𝑜𝑟𝑚𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑟𝑡 (1 for informal,  0 for 
formal).  We control  for a vector of covariates,  𝑋′
𝑖𝑟𝑡, which comprises  
fixed effects for each age and education  group as in Eq.  (11), as well 
as marital  status, an urban-area  dummy,  gender,  and an indicator  for 
having at least one child under 18. We also control  for region-year  
fixed effects, 𝜃𝑟×𝑡, thereby  absorbing  region-level  shocks and deflating  
for the annual income  variable.  𝑣𝑖𝑟𝑡 is the error term clustered  at the 
region level. We use sampling  weights  when running  the regression.  
The estimate  of 𝜏 represents  the difference  in real annual earned income  
between  informally  and formally  employed  workers.
Table  8 reports the results.  Column  (1) shows the simple regression  
result, while column  (2) presents  the estimate  obtained  after including  
the full set of controls.  Results  in both columns  suggest  that having an 
informal  job (versus  formal employment)  is associated  with a reduction  
in annual earned income  of approximately  28.6% (= [𝑒−0.337− 1] × 100 ) 
to 43.3% (= [𝑒−0.568− 1] × 100 ).
Taken together,  the results from this subsection  paint the following  
picture:  compared  to formally  employed  workers,  those with informal  
jobs are younger,  less educated,  and earn lower income.  These findings  
suggest  that informal  employment  represents  a form of precarious  
work, providing  a buffer against  full unemployment  for individuals  
with sufficiently  low reservation  wages, provided  that local labor de-
mand supports  it. Therefore,  it is perhaps  unsurprising  that the increase  
in unemployment  due to the minimum  wage observed  in our earlier 
analysis  is accompanied  by a rise in informal  employment.Table 8

5. Does the Russian  minimum  wage policy help the poor?
The minimum-wage  policy is designed  to assist individuals  at the 
lower end of the income  distribution.  However,  according  to our find-
ings, in Russia, this policy leads to job losses among workers  under 
30 years of age and an increase  in the proportion  of workers  employed  
informally.  Given these findings,  it is natural  to question  whether  the 
policy meaningfully  aids the poorest.
To examine  the implications  of the minimum  wage policy for family 
income,  we adopt an approach  deployed  in Dube (2019 ). Specifically,  
Dube estimates  the household  income  effects of the policy by fitting the 
following  specification:  
𝐼𝑐𝑖𝑟𝑡=3∑
𝑘=−1𝛼𝑐𝑘log(𝑀𝑊𝑟(𝑡−𝑘)) +𝑋𝑖𝑟𝑡𝛹𝑐+𝛩+𝛾𝑟𝑡+𝜖𝑐𝑖𝑟𝑡 (12)
The outcome  variable  is an indicator  of the 𝑖th individual  observed  
in region 𝑟 at time 𝑡 in a family whose value of equalized  income  
divided  by the federal poverty  threshold  falls below 𝑐. For example,  the 
observation  with 𝐼1𝑖𝑟𝑡= 1 indicates  that the individual’s  family is below 
the official poverty  threshold.  Similarly,  𝐼0.5𝑖𝑟𝑡= 1 indicates  that the 
equalized  income  of the 𝑖th individual’s  household  is below 0.5 times Economic  Modelling  148 (2025)  107086

the official poverty  rate. Following  the baseline  analysis  in Dube’s work, 
we consider  the values of 𝑐 between  0.5 and 1.75 in increments  of 0.25.
In Dube (2019 ), the set of key variables  of interest  includes  con-
temporaneous,  one-year  leading,  and three-year  lagged values of the 
real minimum  wage. The model also incorporates  individual-level  char-
acteristics  (quartic  age, gender,  race, education,  family size, number  
of children,  and marital  status) and state-level  macroeconomic  indi-
cators (unemployment  rate, income  per capita, and EITC supplement)  
on its right-hand  side. The term 𝛩 includes  the region fixed effect, 
division-year  fixed effect, and the region fixed effect interacted  with 
the indicators  of recessionary  years (2007–2009);  𝛾𝑠𝑡 represents  the 
region-specific  linear trend, and 𝜖𝑐𝑖𝑠𝑡 denotes  the error term.
Our replication  exercise  deviates  from the original  estimation  strat-
egy of Dube (2019 ) in three ways. First, Russia does not have an 
equivalent  of the EITC program.  Second,  microdata  on households  are unavailable  for the recessionary  years. Finally,  our dataset  lacks 
information  on the ethnicity  of respondents.  Besides  the exclusion  of 
the above information  from the set of control  variables,  our set of 
controls  is analogous  to that employed  in Dube (2019 ). Additionally,  
we narrow  the focus of our analysis  to the working-age  population,  
resulting  in a final sample of 373,555  individuals.
Using the set of estimated  coefficients  of the minimum  wage vari-
ables from Eq.  (12), we calculate  the long-run  elasticity  of the pro-
portion  of individuals  falling below the income-to-needs  cutoff, 𝑐, with 
respect  to the minimum  wage by estimating  the following  expression:

Table  9 presents  the estimated  elasticities  for different  income  
cutoffs.  Column  (1) shows multiples  of the federal poverty  threshold.  
Column  (2) reports baseline  results retrieved  from the original  U.S. 
study by Dube (2019 ).11 Column  (3) presents  the results obtained  using 
our data. Contrasting  the results reported  in columns  (2)–(3),  we ob-
serve that poverty  in Russia is less sensitive  to changes  in the minimum  
wage. For instance,  in the United States, the estimated  reduction  in 
the proportions  of individuals  falling below 50% and 100% of the 
federal poverty  threshold  in response  to a one-unit  change  in 𝐿𝑜𝑔(𝑀𝑊 )
is −0.455 and −0.446, respectively.  However,  in Russia, the estimated  
elasticities  are −0.048 and −0.070. The numerical  values of estimated  
elasticities  decrease  in both countries  as the income-to-needs  cutoff, 𝑐, 
increases.
The results in this section indicate  the relatively  limited  effec-
tiveness  of the Russian  minimum  wage as a poverty-alleviating  tool 
compared  to the same policy in the United States. Job losses among 
young workers  and the informalization  of the Russian  labor market,  
both induced  by minimum  wage increases,  are two natural  explanations  
for this finding.
6. Conclusion
This paper assesses  the employment  effects of the minimum  wage 
policy in Russia. We first investigate  whether  regional  unemployment  
rates respond  to the rising wage floor. Our results suggest  that overall 
unemployment  rates remain unchanged,  while young workers  (those 
aged under 30) are affected.  The point estimates  indicate  that a one-
percentage-point  increase  in the real minimum  wage raises unemploy-
ment rates among teenagers  (15–19  years old) and young workers  
(20–29  years old) by 0.046 and 0.056 percentage  points, respectively.  
We also provide  evidence  of a redistribution  of workers  toward  the in-
formal sector resulting  from the implementation  of a higher wage floor. 
Our estimates  are robust to alternative  model specifications.  We also 
show that our findings  hold when we employ  an alternative  empirical

Notes: This table reports the long-run (3 years) elasticities  of the share with family 
income under various multiples  of the federal poverty threshold  with respect to the 
minimum  wage. The multiples  of the federal poverty threshold  are listed in Column 
(1). Column (2) shows the U.S. estimates  obtained from Dube (2019 ), and Column (3) 
presents the authors’ estimates  obtained from a nearly analogous  empirical  exercise 
using Russian data. Robust standard errors, clustered  by state (Column 2) or region 
(Column 3), are reported in parentheses.  +, *, and ** denote significance  at the 10%, 
5%, and 1% levels, respectively.
design:  a one-percentage-point  increase  in the nominal  minimum  wage 
in Kamchatka  raised the share of unemployed  youth by 0.05 percentage  
points. This finding  also passes a set of robustness  checks.
Next, we investigate  whether  the estimated  employment  effects of 
the minimum  wage policy differ across industries.  We show that indus-
tries with a greater  capacity  to substitute  capital for labor are more 
likely to experience  steeper  losses in youth employment.  However,  
when substitution  is not feasible  due to the underlying  production  
technology,  industries  tend to employ  more workers  informally  when 
the minimum  wage increases.  Consequently,  we infer that differences  
in employers’  ability to substitute  labor with capital and formal workers  
with informal  ones — factors that vary across countries  and time peri-
ods — help explain  the variation  in estimated  unemployment  effects of 
minimum  wages across studies.
Lastly, we assess the effectiveness  of Russia’s  minimum  wage policy 
as a poverty  alleviation  tool. Consistent  with observed  job losses among 
youth and rising informal  employment,  we find its impact on work-
ers’ income  to be minimal.  These findings  cast doubt on the policy’s  
effectiveness  in supporting  low-income  families,  its primary  objective.
It is important  to acknowledge  some limitations  of our analysis  that 
may open avenues  for future research.  First, our study focuses  on a 
short time frame, covering  the years 2009–2013.  This period follows  
the global financial  crisis of 2008 and precedes  the economic  downturn  
triggered  by the annexation  of Crimea  in 2014. Future research  could 
examine  the implications  of the minimum  wage using data spanning  a 
longer period while isolating  the effects of a higher wage floor from 
broader  macroeconomic  shocks.  These shocks — driven by import 
restrictions  and domestic  monetary  policy — could also be leveraged  
to explore  possible  heterogeneity  in the minimum  wage effect under 
different  macroeconomic  conditions.
Next, a recent advancement  in the difference-in-differences  and two-
way fixed effects literature  has highlighted  the fragility  of estimated  
minimum  wage effects in the presence  of staggered  policy adoption  
and heterogeneity  in its effects (Dube and Lindner , 2024 ). Relatedly,  
Callaway  and Sant’Anna  (2021 ) discuss a family of estimators  de-
signed to address  these concerns.  The authors  also demonstrate  an 
application  of one of their proposed  methods  by aggregating  multi-
ple individual  cases of minimum  wage increases  into a generalized  
event-study  research  design using U.S. data. Specifically,  they select 
a time window,  2001–2007,  during which the federal minimum  wage 
remained  unchanged.  With this ‘‘clean’’  control  group in hand, they Economic  Modelling  148 (2025)  107086  
13 
----------------------------------------

[Page 14 of 15]
G.K. Ten and S. Wang
Fig. 6. Proportion  of employed  individuals  with informal jobs, by education  group.
Notes: The unit of observation  is the individual.  𝑁 = 323,290.  The 𝑦-axis shows the estimated  difference  in the proportion  of employed  individuals  with informal jobs between the 
education  group specified on the 𝑥-axis and those without any secondary  education.  Circles represent  estimates  obtained from the model without control variables,  while diamonds  
represent  those obtained from the model with a full set of controls. The controls comprise  age group, marital status, an urban-area  dummy, gender, an indicator  of having at least 
one child under 18, and region-year  fixed effects. Vertical bars represent  95% confidence  intervals calculated  using standard errors clustered  by region.
estimate  employment  effects by leveraging  variation  in the minimum  
wage stemming  from states that adopted  higher wage floors at different  
points within this period.  Notably,  Cengiz et al. (2019 ) adopt a similar 
approach  to constructing  a ‘‘clean’’  control  group in their analysis.
These advancements  may prompt  efforts to construct  a ‘‘clean’’  
control  group in Russia, where the minimum  wage remains  unchanged  
for a sufficiently  long period.  The primary  challenge,  however,  is the 
high frequency  of minimum  wage adjustments  in Russia compared  
to the U.S. Specifically,  as Dube and Lindner  (2024 ) pointedly  note, 
local wage-floor  increases  in the U.S. between  1980 and 2019 largely 
occurred  in three waves: Once in the 1980s and twice in the 2000s. 
Combined  with long periods  of respite from federal minimum  wage 
increases,  this pattern  allows for various  comparisons  of employment  
trends between  treated  states and a ‘‘clean’’  control  group. Meanwhile,  
the Russian  government  strives to raise the federal wage floor on an 
annual basis, making  it particularly  challenging  to identify  a control  
group where the minimum  wage remains  unchanged  for a sufficiently  
long period.
At a broader  level, of course,  further research  is required  to obtain 
a bigger picture of the ramifications  of the minimum  wage increase  
on the economy,  as well as the role of firm-level  technology  and the 
prevalence  of informality  in the labor market.  For example,  a strand 
of literature  examines  the implications  of the minimum  wage for non-
labor outcomes,  such as food consumption  choices  (e.g., Clark et al., 
2020 ), health (e.g., Liu et al., 2024 ; Neumark , 2024 ), and the gender 
pay gap (e.g., Majchrowska  and Strawiński , 2018 ). Future research  may 
investigate  the potential  heterogeneity  of these effects depending  on the 
substitutability  of production  inputs and the extent of noncompliance  
with the policy in question.  Additionally,  there is a rich literature  
on skill-biased  technological  change  and its implications  for the wage 
distribution  (e.g., Card and DiNardo , 2002 ; Mallick  and Sousa , 2017 ), 
which opens the door to empirical  explorations  of the effects of skill-
biased technological  change  on the magnitude  of the minimum  wage 
elasticity  of labor demand.  The ongoing  discussion  of the evolution  of college wage premium  over time (e.g., Fortin , 2006 ; Boero et al., 2025 ) 
may also prompt  an investigation  into the role of the minimum  wage 
— and the forces moderating  its impact — in shaping  wage gaps among 
workers  with different  levels of education.  Lastly, a nascent  literature  
explores  the effect of raising the wage floor on the non-profit  sector 
(e.g., Balsam  et al., 2023 ; Meer and Tajali , 2023 ), making  it natural  to 
inquire  whether  the capital-labor  substitution  hypothesis  investigated  
in our paper can be tested in firms whose main objective  function  
differs from profit maximization.

The authors  Gi Khan Ten and Shun Wang declare  no interest  con-
flict.

[Page 1 of 6]
Finance Research Letters 61 (2024) 104973
Available online 3 January 20241544-6123/© 2024 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.Minimum wage and internal income disparity within enterprises Hao Lia,*, Xiaoxue Jub aRural Development Institute, Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, Beijing, 100732, China bPeoples’ Friendship University of Russia, Moscow, 117198, Russia   ARTICLE INFO  Keywords: Internal income disparity Minimum wage ABSTRACT  The internal income gap within enterprises refers to the differences in compensation among employees within the same company. This paper takes non-financial listed companies in China as the research subject and empirically tests the impact of the regional minimum wage standards on the internal income disparity within enterprises. The study results indicate that higher regional minimum wage standards are conducive to narrowing the internal income disparities within enterprises. Heterogeneity analysis shows that the restraining effect of minimum wage standards on internal income disparity is more pronounced in enterprises located in regions with lower levels of marketization and in small-scale enterprises.   1.Introduction The cost effect for enterprises is primarily manifested when changes in the minimum wage affect the costs required to employ labor. Implementing a minimum wage protection system has, to some extent, promoted the establishment of a harmonious society and created reasonable compensation standards for company development. However, since such standards are the basis for well- distributed internal allocation, companies can implement more in-depth reforms of the internal compensation structure according to these standards. In addition, the minimum wage standard has a cost effect; changes in the minimum wage standard can lead to an increase in the average wage of the enterprise and a decrease in the operating capacity of the enterprise (Draca et al., 2011). The internal pay gap within an enterprise is a key link in the design of the enterprise’s compensation system, involving the issue of compensation distribution, that is, the reasonable allocation between labor and management elements (Xu and Wang, 2023). Scientific and rational compensation management and designing a hierarchical compensation system are not only related to the economic benefits and innovative development of the enterprise but are more importantly related to the immediate interests of each worker and even the national income distribution pattern. Therefore, a deep understanding and increased awareness of the internal wage gap can help enterprises formulate more reasonable internal compensation distribution policies and make optimal compensation incentive decisions. Particularly, focusing on and resolving the issue of internal pay disparity helps establish a more equitable and sustainable compensation system, promotes employee motivation, and also has a positive impact on the overall income distribution in society (Han et al., 2021). The findings of this paper indicate that the minimum wage standard can narrow the internal income disparity within enterprises. Further heterogeneity analysis results show that the minimum wage standard plays a significant role in alleviating internal income disparity in enterprises in high-marketization areas and in smaller-scale enterprises. This paper makes several distinct contributions to the existing body of research on minimum wage standards and their socio- *Corresponding author. E-mail address: nfs-lihao@cass.org.cn (H. Li).  
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect Finance Research Letters journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/frl 
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.frl.2024.104973 Received 23 November 2023; Received in revised form 13 December 2023; Accepted 2 January 2024
